[The man]315-the man 's motor was small and swift like [himself]315-the man ; in fact , like [his]315-the man domestic service , it was of [his]315-the man own invention . If [he]315-the man was [an advertising quack]1555-an advertising quack , [he]315-the man was one who believed in [his]315-the man own wares . The sense of something tiny and flying was accentuated as [they]1556-they swept up long white curves of [road]1557-road in the dead but open daylight of evening . Soon the white curves came sharper and dizzier ; they were upon ascending spirals , as [they]1556-they say in the modern religions . For , indeed , [they]1556-they were cresting [a corner of [London]4-london which is almost as precipitous as [Edinburgh]61-edinburgh]1558-a corner of london which is almost as precipitous as edinburgh , if not quite so picturesque . Terrace rose above [terrace]1559-terrace , and [the special tower of [flats]1561-flats [they]1556-they sought]1560-the special tower of flats they sought , rose above [them]1556-they all to almost Egyptian height , gilt by the level sunset . These were the only human shapes in [that high suburban solitude]1576-that high suburban solitude ; but [he]181-angus had an irrational sense that they expressed the speechless poetry of [London]4-london . [He]181-angus felt as if they were figures in a story .

[The little car]1577-the little car shot up to [the right house]1578-the right house like a bullet , and shot out [its owner]1579-its owner like a bomb shell . [He]181-angus was immediately inquiring of [a tall commissionaire in shining braid]1580-a tall commissionaire in shining braid , and a short porter in shirt sleeves , whether [anybody]371-anybody or anything had been seeking [[his]181-angus apartments]1582-his apartments . "[186-smythe] [He]186-smythe pressed a button concealed in the wall , and the door opened of itself .

It opened on [a long , commodious ante - room]1588-a long , commodious ante - room , of which the only arresting features , ordinarily speaking , were the rows of tall half - human mechanical figures that stood up on both sides like [tailors]1589-tailors ' dummies . Like [tailors]1589-tailors ' dummies [they]1586-they were headless ; and like [tailors]1589-tailors ' dummies [they]1586-they had a handsome unnecessary humpiness in the shoulders , and a pigeon - breasted protuberance of chest ; but barring this , [they]1586-they were not much more like a human figure than any automatic machine at [a station]1592-a station that is about the human height . [They]1586-they had two great hooks like arms , for carrying trays ; and they were painted pea - green , or vermilion , or black for convenience of distinction ; in every other way they were only automatic machines and [nobody]329-nobody would have looked twice at them . On this occasion , at least , [nobody]329-nobody did . For between the two rows of these domestic dummies lay something more interesting than most of the mechanics of [the world]322-the world . It was a white , tattered scrap of paper scrawled with red ink ; and [the agile inventor]1596-the agile inventor had snatched it up almost as soon as the door flew open . [He]1596-the agile inventor handed it to [Angus]181-angus without a word . The red ink on it actually was not dry , and the message ran , " If [you]181-angus have been to see [her]3738-your friend today , [I]182-smythe shall kill [you]181-angus . "[182-smythe]

There was a short silence , and then [Isidore Smythe]182-smythe said quietly , " Would [you]181-angus like a little whiskey ? [I]182-smythe rather feel as if [I]182-smythe should . "[182-smythe]

It showed substantially the same serried interior ; [the hall]1000-the hall had grown darker , though [it]1000-the hall was still struck here and there with the last crimson shafts of sunset , and one or two of the headless machines had been moved from [their]1654-their places for this or that purpose , and stood here and there about [the twilit place]1655-the twilit place . The green and red of [their]1654-their coats were all darkened in the dusk ; and [their]1654-their likeness to human shapes slightly increased by their very shapelessness . But in the middle of [them]1654-their all , exactly where the paper with the red ink had lain , there lay something that looked like red ink spilt out of its bottle . But it was not red ink .

"[181-angus]

" [I]121-father brown beg [your]181-angus pardon , "[121-father brown] said [Father Brown]121-father brown ; " that is [my]121-father brown fault . The Honour of [Israel Gow]192-israel gow

A stormy evening of olive and silver was closing in , as [Father Brown]121-father brown , wrapped in a grey Scotch plaid , came to the end of [a grey Scotch valley]1704-a grey scotch valley and beheld [the strange castle of Glengyle]1705-the strange castle of glengyle . [It]1705-the strange castle of glengyle stopped [one end of [the glen]1707-the glen]1706-one end of the glen or hollow like [a blind alley]1708-a blind alley ; and [it]1705-the strange castle of glengyle looked like the end of [the world]322-the world . Rising in steep roofs and spires of seagreen slate in the manner of [the old French - Scotch chateaux]1710-the old french - scotch chateaux , [it]1705-the strange castle of glengyle reminded [an Englishman of the sinister steeple - hats of witches]1711-an englishman of the sinister steeple - hats of witches in fairy tales ; and [the pine woods that rocked round [the green turrets]1713-the green turrets]1712-the pine woods that rocked round the green turrets looked , by comparison , as black as numberless flocks of ravens . This note of a dreamy , almost a sleepy devilry , was no mere fancy from [the landscape]1714-the landscape . For there did rest on the place one of those clouds of pride and madness and mysterious sorrow which lie more heavily on [the noble houses of [Scotland]63-scotland]1715-the noble houses of scotland than on [any other of [the children of [men]3431-men]1717-the children of men]1716-any other of the children of men . For [Scotland]63-scotland has a double dose of the poison called heredity ; the sense of blood in [the aristocrat]1719-the aristocrat , and the sense of doom in [the Calvinist]1720-the calvinist .

[The priest]374-the priest had snatched a day from [his]374-the priest business at [Glasgow]64-glasgow to meet [[his]374-the priest friend]3351-his friend [Flambeau]111-flambeau , [the amateur detective , who was at [Glengyle Castle]65-glengyle castle]1723-the amateur detective , who was at glengyle castle with [another more formal officer investigating the life and death of the late Earl of [Glengyle]66-glengyle]1724-another more formal officer investigating the life and death of the late earl of glengyle . [That mysterious person]1725-that mysterious person was [the last representative of [a race whose valour , insanity , and violent cunning]1727-a race whose valour , insanity , and violent cunning had made [them]1727-a race whose valour , insanity , and violent cunning terrible even among [the sinister nobility of [their]1727-a race whose valour , insanity , and violent cunning nation]1728-the sinister nobility of their nation in the sixteenth century]1726-the last representative of a race whose valour , insanity , and violent cunning had made them terrible even among the sinister nobility of their nation in the sixteenth century . None were deeper in that labyrinthine ambition , in [chamber within chamber of [that palace of lies that was built up around [Mary Queen of Scots]190-mary queen of scots]1730-that palace of lies that was built up around mary queen of scots]1729-chamber within chamber of that palace of lies that was built up around mary queen of scots .

The rhyme in [the country - side]1731-the country - side attested the motive and the result of [their]1727-a race whose valour , insanity , and violent cunning machinations candidly : As green sap to the simmer trees Is red gold to [the Ogilvies]191-the ogilvies .

For many centuries there had never been [a decent lord]1732-a decent lord in [Glengyle Castle]65-glengyle castle ; and with the Victorian era one would have thought that all eccentricities were exhausted . [The last Glengyle]1733-the last glengyle , however , satisfied [his]1733-the last glengyle tribal tradition by doing the only thing that was left for [him]1733-the last glengyle to do ; [he]1733-the last glengyle disappeared . [I]0-i do not mean that [he]1733-the last glengyle went abroad ; by all accounts [he]1733-the last glengyle was still in [the castle]1734-the castle , if [he]1733-the last glengyle was anywhere . But though [his]1733-the last glengyle name was in the church register and the big red Peerage , [nobody]329-nobody ever saw [him]1733-the last glengyle under the sun .

If [anyone]798-anyone saw [him]1733-the last glengyle it was [a solitary man - servant]1737-a solitary man - servant , something between [a groom]1738-a groom and [a gardener]1739-a gardener . [He]1733-the last glengyle was so deaf that [the more business - like]1740-the more business - like assumed [him]1733-the last glengyle to be dumb ; while [the more penetrating]1741-the more penetrating declared [him]1733-the last glengyle to be half - witted . [A gaunt , red - haired labourer , with a dogged jaw and chin]1742-a gaunt , red - haired labourer , with a dogged jaw and chin , but quite blank blue eyes , [he]1733-the last glengyle went by the name of [Israel Gow]192-israel gow , and was [the one silent servant on [that deserted estate]1744-that deserted estate]1743-the one silent servant on that deserted estate . But the energy with which [he]1733-the last glengyle dug potatoes , and the regularity with which [he]1733-the last glengyle disappeared into [the kitchen]1745-the kitchen gave [people]338-people an impression that [he]1733-the last glengyle was providing for the meals of [a superior]1747-a superior , and that [the strange earl]1748-the strange earl was still concealed in [the castle]1734-the castle . If [society]936-society needed any further proof that [he]1733-the last glengyle was [there]777-there , [the servant]805-the servant persistently asserted that [he]1733-the last glengyle was not at [home]3338-home . One morning [the provost]1754-the provost and [the minister for [the Glengyles]193-the glengyles]1755-the minister for the glengyles were [Presbyterian]1756-presbyterian were summoned to [the castle]1734-the castle . There [they]1758-they found that [the gardener]1759-the gardener , [groom]1760-groom and [cook]1761-cook had added to [his]1733-the last glengyle many professions that of [an undertaker]1762-an undertaker , and had nailed up [[his]1733-the last glengyle noble master]1763-his noble master in a coffin . With how much or how little further inquiry this odd fact was passed , did not as yet very plainly appear ; for the thing had never been legally investigated till [Flambeau]111-flambeau had gone north two or three days before . By then the body of [Lord Glengyle]194-lord glengyle if it was the body had lain for some time in [the little churchyard on [the hill]1765-the hill]1764-the little churchyard on the hill .

As [Father Brown]121-father brown passed through [the dim garden]1766-the dim garden and came under the shadow of [the chateau]1767-the chateau , the clouds were thick and the whole air damp and thundery . Against the last stripe of the green - gold sunset [he]121-father brown saw [a black human silhouette]1768-a black human silhouette ; [a man in a chimney - pot hat , with a big spade over [his]1769-a man in a chimney - pot hat , with a big spade over his shoulder shoulder]1769-a man in a chimney - pot hat , with a big spade over his shoulder . The combination was queerly suggestive of [a sexton]1770-a sexton ; but when [Brown]121-father brown remembered [the deaf servant who dug potatoes]1771-the deaf servant who dug potatoes , [he]121-father brown thought it natural enough . [He]121-father brown knew something of [the Scotch peasant]1772-the scotch peasant ; [he]121-father brown knew the respectability which might well feel it necessary to wear " blacks "[121-father brown] for an official inquiry ; [he]121-father brown knew also the economy that would not lose an hour 's digging for that . Even [the man]315-the man 's start and suspicious stare as [the priest]374-the priest went by were consonant enough with the vigilance and jealousy of such a type .

The great door was opened by [Flambeau]111-flambeau [himself]111-flambeau , who had with [him]111-flambeau [a lean man with iron - grey hair]1775-a lean man with iron - grey hair and papers in [his]1775-a lean man with iron - grey hair hand : [Inspector Craven]195-craven from [Scotland Yard]14-scotland yard . [The entrance hall]623-the entrance hall was mostly stripped and empty ; but the pale , sneering faces of [one or two of [the wicked Ogilvies]1778-the wicked ogilvies]1777-one or two of the wicked ogilvies looked down out of black periwigs and blackening canvas .

Following [them]1779-them into [an inner room]1780-an inner room , [Father Brown]121-father brown found that [the allies]1781-the allies had been seated at a long oak table , of which [their]1781-the allies end was covered with scribbled papers , flanked with whisky and cigars . Through the whole of [its]1782-its remaining length it was occupied by detached objects arranged at intervals ; objects about as inexplicable as any objects could be . One looked like a small heap of glittering broken glass . Another looked like a high heap of brown dust . A third appeared to be a plain stick of wood .

" [You]1783-the police detective seem to have a sort of geological museum here , "[121-father brown] [he]121-father brown said , as [he]121-father brown sat down , jerking [his]121-father brown head briefly in the direction of the brown dust and the crystalline fragments .

" [We]4093-we must get a candle , "[196-craven] said [Craven]196-craven , suddenly . " A storm is getting up , and it 's too dark to read . "[196-craven]

" Have [you]111-flambeau found any candles , "[121-father brown] asked [Brown]121-father brown smiling , " among [your]111-flambeau oddities ? "[121-father brown]

" That is curious , too , "[111-flambeau] [he]111-flambeau said . " Twenty - five candles , and not a trace of a candlestick . "[111-flambeau]

In the rapidly darkening room and rapidly rising wind , [Brown]121-father brown went along the table to where a bundle of wax candles lay among the other scrappy exhibits . As [he]121-father brown did so [he]121-father brown bent accidentally over the heap of red - brown dust ; and a sharp sneeze cracked the silence .

" Hullo ! "[121-father brown] [he]121-father brown said , ' snuff ! "[121-father brown]

[He]121-father brown took one of the candles , lit it carefully , came back and stuck it in the neck of the whisky bottle . The unrestful night air , blowing through the crazy window , waved the long flame like a banner . And on every side of [the castle]1734-the castle [they]1787-they could hear the miles and miles of black pine wood seething like a black sea around a rock .

" [I]196-craven will read the inventory , "[196-craven] began [Craven]196-craven gravely , picking up one of the papers , " the inventory of what [we]4093-we found loose and unexplained in [the castle]1734-the castle . [You]4095-you are to understand that [the place]3350-the place generally was dismantled and neglected ; but [one or two rooms]4097-one or two rooms had plainly been inhabited in a simple but not squalid style by [somebody]3425-somebody ; [somebody who was not [the servant Gow]4100-the servant gow]4099-somebody who was not the servant gow . The list is as follows :[196-craven]

" First item . A very considerable hoard of precious stones , nearly all diamonds , and all of them loose , without any setting whatever . Of course , it is natural that [the Ogilvies]4101-the ogilvies should have family jewels ; but those are exactly the jewels that are almost always set in particular articles of ornament . [The Ogilvies]191-the ogilvies would seem to have kept theirs loose in [their]191-the ogilvies pockets , like coppers .[196-craven]

" Second item . Heaps and heaps of loose snuff , not kept in a horn , or even a pouch , but lying in heaps on the mantelpieces , on the sideboard , on the piano , anywhere . It looks as if [the old gentleman]4102-the old gentleman would not take the trouble to look in a pocket or lift a lid .[196-craven]

" Third item . Here and there about [the house]630-the house curious little heaps of minute pieces of metal , some like steel springs and some in the form of microscopic wheels . As if they had gutted some mechanical toy .[196-craven]

" Fourth item . The wax candles , which have to be stuck in bottle necks because there is nothing else to stick them in . Now [I]196-craven wish [you]4095-you to note how very much queerer all this is than anything [we]4093-we anticipated . For the central riddle [we]4093-we are prepared ; [we]4093-we have all seen at a glance that there was something wrong about [the last earl]4104-the last earl . [We]4093-we have come here to find out whether [he]4104-the last earl really lived [here]3296-here , whether [he]4104-the last earl really died here , whether [that red - haired scarecrow who did [his]4104-the last earl burying]4106-that red - haired scarecrow who did his burying had anything to do with [his]4104-the last earl dying . But suppose the worst in all this , the most lurid or melodramatic solution [you]4095-you like . Suppose [the servant]805-the servant really killed [the master]4108-the master , or suppose [the master]4108-the master is n't really dead , or suppose [the master]4108-the master is dressed up as [the servant]805-the servant , or suppose [the servant]805-the servant is buried for [the master]4108-the master ; invent what [Wilkie Collins]197-wilkie collins ' tragedy [you]4095-you like , and [you]4095-you still have not explained a candle without a candlestick , or why [an elderly gentleman of good family]4114-an elderly gentleman of good family should habitually spill snuff on the piano . The core of the tale [we]4093-we could imagine ; it is the fringes that are mysterious . By no stretch of fancy can the human mind connect together snuff and diamonds and wax and loose clockwork . "[196-craven]

" [I]374-the priest think [I]374-the priest see the connection , "[374-the priest] said [the priest]374-the priest . " [This Glengyle]66-glengyle was mad against the French Revolution . [He]374-the priest was [an enthusiast for the ancien regime]4115-an enthusiast for the ancien regime , and was trying to re - enact literally the family life of [the last Bourbons]198-the last bourbons . [He]374-the priest had snuff because it was the eighteenth century luxury ; wax candles , because they were the eighteenth century lighting ; the mechanical bits of iron represent the locksmith hobby of [Louis XVI]199-louis xvi ; the diamonds are for the Diamond Necklace of [Marie Antoinette]200-marie antoinette . "[374-the priest]

[Both the other men]1789-both the other men were staring at [him]374-the priest with round eyes . " What a perfectly extraordinary notion ! "[111-flambeau] cried [Flambeau]111-flambeau . " Do [you]121-father brown really think that is the truth ? "[111-flambeau]

" [I]121-father brown am perfectly sure it is n't , "[121-father brown] answered [Father Brown]121-father brown , " only [you]121-father brown said that [nobody]329-nobody could connect snuff and diamonds and clockwork and candles . [He]121-father brown paused a moment and listened to the wailing of the wind in [the turrets]1790-the turrets . The bough of a broken pine tree lashed heavily in the blast against the windowpane behind [them]1791-them , as if in parody of [a burglar]3761-a burglar , but [they]1791-them did not turn round . [Their]1791-them eyes were fastened on [Father Brown]121-father brown .

" Diamonds and small wheels , "[196-craven] repeated [Craven]196-craven ruminating . " Is that all that makes [you]121-father brown think it the true explanation ? "[196-craven]

"[374-the priest]

" Now , "[1798-the astonished detective] repeated [the astonished detective]1798-the astonished detective , " and why now ? "[1798-the astonished detective]

" Because this is serious , "[121-father brown] answered [Brown]121-father brown ; " this is not spilt snuff or loose pebbles , that might be there for a hundred reasons . There is only one reason [I]121-father brown know of for this being done ; and the reason goes down to the roots of [the world]322-the world . These religious pictures are not just dirtied or torn or scrawled over , which might be done in idleness or bigotry , by [children]4140-children or by [Protestants]202-protestants . These have been treated very carefully - and very queerly . In every place where the great ornamented name of [God]120-god comes in the old illuminations it has been elaborately taken out . [[His]121-father brown comrades]1802-his comrades hardly knew that [they]1802-his comrades had obeyed and followed [him]121-father brown till a blast of the night wind nearly flung [them]1802-his comrades on [their]1802-his comrades faces in [the garden]629-the garden . The path up [the hill]1765-the hill to [the churchyard]1806-the churchyard was crooked but short ; only under that stress of wind it seemed laborious and long . Far as the eye could see , farther and farther as [they]1807-they mounted [the slope]1808-the slope , were seas beyond seas of pines , now all aslope one way under the wind . And that universal gesture seemed as vain as it was vast , as vain as if that wind were whistling about [some unpeopled and purposeless planet]1809-some unpeopled and purposeless planet . Through all that infinite growth of grey - blue forests sang , shrill and high , that ancient sorrow that is in the heart of all heathen things . [One]412-one could fancy that the voices from [the under world of unfathomable foliage]1811-the under world of unfathomable foliage were cries of [the lost and wandering pagan gods]1812-the lost and wandering pagan gods : [gods who had gone roaming in [that irrational forest]1814-that irrational forest , and who will never find [their]1813-gods who had gone roaming in that irrational forest , and who will never find their way back to heaven way back to heaven]1813-gods who had gone roaming in that irrational forest , and who will never find their way back to heaven .

All the corners of the sky were brightening into blue and silver ; the birds were chattering in the tiny garden trees ; so loud it seemed as if the trees themselves were talking . But [the three men]1858-the three men were silent enough .

" Well , [I]111-flambeau give it all up , "[111-flambeau] said [Flambeau]111-flambeau at last boisterously . " [[My]111-flambeau friend]3397-my friend , "[111-flambeau] said [Flambeau]111-flambeau , with a grim humour , " [you]3397-my friend must be careful with [me]111-flambeau and remember [I]111-flambeau was once [a criminal]4177-a criminal . [Father Brown]121-father brown 's pipe fell out of [his]121-father brown mouth and broke into three pieces on [the gravel path]1859-the gravel path . " [The dentist]4179-the dentist ! "[121-father brown] [he]121-father brown repeated . " Six hours in [the spiritual abyss]4183-the spiritual abyss , and all because [I]121-father brown never thought of [the dentist]4179-the dentist ! "[121-father brown]

" [I]111-flambeau will get some sense out of this , "[111-flambeau] cried [Flambeau]111-flambeau , striding forward , " if [I]111-flambeau use the tortures of [the Inquisition]4189-the inquisition . "[111-flambeau]

[Father Brown]121-father brown repressed what appeared to be a momentary disposition to dance on [the now sunlit lawn]1861-the now sunlit lawn and cried quite piteously , like [a child]890-a child , " Oh , let [me]890-a child be silly a little . [You]3637-friends do n't know how unhappy [I]890-a child have been . And now [I]890-a child know that there has been no deep sin in this business at all . [He]121-father brown spun round once more , then faced [them]1863-them with gravity .

" This is not a story of crime , "[121-father brown] [he]121-father brown said ; " rather it is the story of a strange and crooked honesty . [We]4186-we are dealing with [the one man on [earth]3378-earth]4190-the one man on earth , perhaps , who has taken no more than [his]4190-the one man on earth due . It is a study in the savage living logic that has been the religion of [this race]4192-this race .[121-father brown]

" That old local rhyme about [the house of [Glengyle]66-glengyle]4193-the house of glengyle - As green sap to the simmer trees Is red gold to [the Ogilvies]191-the ogilvies - was literal as well as metaphorical . It did not merely mean that [the Glengyles]193-the glengyles sought for wealth ; it was also true that [they]193-the glengyles literally gathered gold ; [they]193-the glengyles had a huge collection of ornaments and utensils in that metal . [They]193-the glengyles were , in fact , [misers whose mania took that turn]4194-misers whose mania took that turn . In the light of that fact , run through all the things [we]4186-we found in [the castle]1734-the castle . Diamonds without [their]193-the glengyles gold rings ; candles without [their]193-the glengyles gold candlesticks ; snuff without the gold snuff - boxes ; pencil - leads without the gold pencil - cases ; a walking stick without its gold top ; clockwork without the gold clocks - or rather watches . And , mad as it sounds , because the halos and the name of [God]120-god in the old missals were of real gold ; these also were taken away . "[890-a child]

[The garden]629-the garden seemed to brighten , the grass to grow gayer in the strengthening sun , as the crazy truth was told . [Flambeau]111-flambeau lit a cigarette as [[his]111-flambeau friend]3351-his friend went on .

" Were taken away , "[121-father brown] continued [Father Brown]121-father brown ; " were taken away - but not stolen . [Thieves]4196-thieves would never have left this mystery . [I]121-father brown found [that mad moralist]4199-that mad moralist this morning in [the kitchen garden yonder]4200-the kitchen garden yonder , and [I]121-father brown heard the whole story .[121-father brown]

" [The late Archibald Ogilvie]204-the late archibald ogilvie was the nearest approach to [a good man]4201-a good man ever born at [Glengyle]66-glengyle . But [his]204-the late archibald ogilvie bitter virtue took the turn of the misanthrope ; [he]204-the late archibald ogilvie moped over the dishonesty of [[his]204-the late archibald ogilvie ancestors]4202-his ancestors , from which , somehow , [he]204-the late archibald ogilvie generalised a dishonesty of [all men]982-all men . More especially [he]204-the late archibald ogilvie distrusted philanthropy or free - giving ; and [he]204-the late archibald ogilvie swore if [he]204-the late archibald ogilvie could find [one man who took [his]204-the late archibald ogilvie exact rights]4204-one man who took his exact rights [he]204-the late archibald ogilvie should have all the gold of [Glengyle]66-glengyle . Having delivered this defiance to [humanity]4205-humanity [he]204-the late archibald ogilvie shut [himself]204-the late archibald ogilvie up , without the smallest expectation of its being answered . One day , however , [a deaf and seemingly senseless lad from [a distant village]4207-a distant village]4206-a deaf and seemingly senseless lad from a distant village brought [him]204-the late archibald ogilvie a belated telegram ; and [Glengyle]201-glengyle , in [his]201-glengyle acrid pleasantry , gave [him]204-the late archibald ogilvie a new farthing . At least [he]204-the late archibald ogilvie thought [he]204-the late archibald ogilvie had done so , but when [he]204-the late archibald ogilvie turned over [his]204-the late archibald ogilvie change [he]204-the late archibald ogilvie found the new farthing still there and [a sovereign]4208-a sovereign gone . The accident offered [him]204-the late archibald ogilvie vistas of sneering speculation . Either way , [the boy]4209-the boy would show the greasy greed of the species . Either [he]4209-the boy would vanish , [a thief]3419-a thief stealing a coin ; or [he]4209-the boy would sneak back with it virtuously , [a snob seeking a reward]4211-a snob seeking a reward . In the middle of that night [Lord Glengyle]194-lord glengyle was knocked up out of [his]194-lord glengyle bed - for [he]194-lord glengyle lived alone - and forced to open the door to [the deaf idiot]4212-the deaf idiot . [The idiot]4213-the idiot brought with [him]194-lord glengyle , not [the sovereign]4214-the sovereign , but exactly nineteen shillings and eleven - pence three - farthings in change .[890-a child]

" Then the wild exactitude of this action took hold of [the mad lord]4215-the mad lord 's brain like fire . [He]194-lord glengyle swore [he]194-lord glengyle was [Diogenes]205-diogenes , that had long sought [an honest man , and at last had found one]4216-an honest man , and at last had found one . And whatever [that queer creature]4221-that queer creature understands , [he]194-lord glengyle understood absolutely [[his]194-lord glengyle lord]4222-his lord 's two fixed ideas : first , that the letter of right is everything ; and second , that [he]194-lord glengyle [himself]194-lord glengyle was to have the gold of [Glengyle]66-glengyle . So far , that is all ; and that is simple . [He]194-lord glengyle has stripped [the house]630-the house of gold , and taken not a grain that was not gold ; not so much as a grain of snuff . " It will be all right . [He]194-lord glengyle will put the skull back in [the grave]4151-the grave , when [he]194-lord glengyle has taken the gold out of the tooth . "[890-a child]

The Wrong Shape

Certain of [the great roads going north out of [London]4-london]1869-the great roads going north out of london continue far into [the country]1870-the country a sort of attenuated and interrupted spectre of [a street]341-a street , with great gaps in [the building]1872-the building , but preserving the line . [Here]3296-here will be [a group of [shops]1875-shops]1874-a group of shops , followed by [a fenced field or paddock]1876-a fenced field or paddock , and then [a famous public - house]1877-a famous public - house , and then perhaps [a market garden]1878-a market garden or [a nursery garden]1879-a nursery garden , and then [one large private house]1880-one large private house , and then [another field]1881-another field and [another inn]1882-another inn , and so on . If [anyone]798-anyone walks along [one of these roads]1884-one of these roads [he]798-anyone will pass [a house which will probably catch [his]798-anyone eye , though [he]798-anyone may not be able to explain [its]1885-a house which will probably catch his eye , though he may not be able to explain its attraction attraction]1885-a house which will probably catch his eye , though he may not be able to explain its attraction . [It]1885-a house which will probably catch his eye , though he may not be able to explain its attraction is [a long , low house]1886-a long , low house , running parallel with [the road]471-the road , painted mostly white and pale green , with [a veranda and sun - blinds]1888-a veranda and sun - blinds , and porches capped with those quaint sort of cupolas like wooden umbrellas that one sees in [some old - fashioned houses]1889-some old - fashioned houses . In fact , [it]1885-a house which will probably catch his eye , though he may not be able to explain its attraction is [an old - fashioned house , very English and very suburban in the good old wealthy [Clapham]71-clapham sense]1890-an old - fashioned house , very english and very suburban in the good old wealthy clapham sense . And yet [the house]630-the house has a look of having been built chiefly for the hot weather . Looking at [its]630-the house white paint and sun - blinds one thinks vaguely of pugarees and even of palm trees . [I]0-i can not trace the feeling to its root ; perhaps [the place]3350-the place was built by [an Anglo - Indian]1893-an anglo - indian .

[Anyone passing [this house]1895-this house]1894-anyone passing this house , [I]0-i say , would be namelessly fascinated by [it]1885-a house which will probably catch his eye , though he may not be able to explain its attraction ; would feel that [it]1885-a house which will probably catch his eye , though he may not be able to explain its attraction was [a place about which some story was to be told]1896-a place about which some story was to be told . And [he]1894-anyone passing this house would have been right , as [you]1897-you shall shortly hear . For this is the story - the story of the strange things that did really happen in it in the Whitsuntide of the year 18 - :

Anyone passing [the house]630-the house on the Thursday before [WhitSunday]72-whitsunday at about half - past four p.m. would have seen the front door open , and [Father Brown]121-father brown , of [the small church of [St. Mungo]206-st. mungo]1899-the small church of st. mungo , come out smoking a large pipe in company with [a very tall French friend of [his]121-father brown]1900-a very tall french friend of his called [Flambeau]111-flambeau , who was smoking a very small cigarette . [These persons]1901-these persons may or may not be of interest to [the reader]977-the reader , but the truth is that [they]1901-these persons were not the only interesting things that were displayed when the front door of [the white - and - green house]1903-the white - and - green house was opened . There are further peculiarities about [this house]1895-this house , which must be described to start with , not only that [the reader]977-the reader may understand this tragic tale , but also that [he]977-the reader may realise what it was that the opening of the door revealed .

[The whole house]1906-the whole house was built upon the plan of a T , but a T with a very long cross piece and a very short tail piece . [The long cross piece]1907-the long cross piece was the frontage that ran along in face of [the street]390-the street , with the front door in the middle ; [it]1906-the whole house was two stories high , and contained nearly [all the important rooms]1909-all the important rooms . The short tail piece , which ran out at the back immediately opposite the front door , was one story high , and consisted only of [two long rooms]1910-two long rooms , the one leading into the other . [The first of [these two rooms]1912-these two rooms]1911-the first of these two rooms was [the study in which [the celebrated Mr. Quinton]207-mr. quinton wrote [his]207-mr. quinton wild Oriental poems and romances]1913-the study in which the celebrated mr. quinton wrote his wild oriental poems and romances . [The farther room]1914-the farther room was [a glass conservatory full of tropical blossoms of quite unique and almost monstrous beauty]1915-a glass conservatory full of tropical blossoms of quite unique and almost monstrous beauty , and on such afternoons as these glowing with gorgeous sunlight . Thus when the hall door was open , [many a passer - by]1916-many a passer - by literally stopped to stare and gasp ; for [he]207-mr. quinton looked down a perspective of [rich apartments]1917-rich apartments to something really like a transformation scene in a fairy play : purple clouds and golden suns and crimson stars that were at once scorchingly vivid and yet transparent and far away .

[Leonard Quinton]208-quinton , [the poet]1918-the poet , had [himself]208-quinton most carefully arranged this effect ; and it is doubtful whether [he]208-quinton so perfectly expressed [his]208-quinton personality in any of [his]208-quinton poems . For [he]208-quinton was [a man who drank and bathed in colours]1919-a man who drank and bathed in colours , who indulged [his]208-quinton lust for colour somewhat to the neglect of form - even of good form . This it was that had turned [his]208-quinton genius so wholly to eastern art and imagery ; to those bewildering carpets or blinding embroideries in which all the colours seem fallen into a fortunate chaos , having nothing to typify or to teach . [He]208-quinton had attempted , not perhaps with complete artistic success , but with acknowledged imagination and invention , to compose epics and love stories reflecting the riot of violent and even cruel colour ; tales of tropical heavens of burning gold or blood - red copper ; of [eastern heroes who rode with twelve - turbaned mitres upon elephants painted purple or peacock green]1920-eastern heroes who rode with twelve - turbaned mitres upon elephants painted purple or peacock green ; of gigantic jewels that [a hundred negroes]1921-a hundred negroes could not carry , but which burned with ancient and strange - hued fires .

In short to put the matter from the more common point of view , [he]208-quinton dealt much in eastern heavens , rather worse than [most western hells]1922-most western hells ; in eastern monarchs , whom [we]1923-we might possibly call [maniacs]1924-maniacs ; and in eastern jewels which [a Bond Street jeweller]1925-a bond street jeweller if [the hundred staggering negroes]1926-the hundred staggering negroes brought [them]1926-the hundred staggering negroes into [[his]1925-a bond street jeweller shop]1927-his shop might possibly not regard as genuine . [Quinton]208-quinton was [a genius]1928-a genius , if [a morbid one]1929-a morbid one ; and even [his]208-quinton morbidity appeared more in [his]208-quinton life than in [his]208-quinton work . In temperament [he]208-quinton was weak and waspish , and [his]208-quinton health had suffered heavily from oriental experiments with opium . [[His]208-quinton wife]1930-his wife - [a handsome , hard - working , and , indeed , over - worked woman]1931-a handsome , hard - working , and , indeed , over - worked woman objected to the opium , but objected much more to [a live Indian hermit in white and yellow robes]1932-a live indian hermit in white and yellow robes , whom [[her]1930-his wife husband]1933-her husband insisted on entertaining for months together , [a Virgil to guide [his]208-quinton spirit through the heavens and [the hells of [the east]1936-the east]1935-the hells of the east]1934-a virgil to guide his spirit through the heavens and the hells of the east .

It was out of [this artistic household]1937-this artistic household that [Father Brown]121-father brown and [[his]121-father brown friend]3351-his friend stepped on to the door - step ; and to judge from [their]1939-they faces , [they]1939-they stepped out of it with much relief . [Flambeau]111-flambeau had known [Quinton]208-quinton in wild student days in [Paris]35-paris , and [they]1939-they had renewed the acquaintance for a week - end ; but apart from [Flambeau]111-flambeau 's more responsible developments of late , [he]111-flambeau did not get on well with [the poet]1918-the poet now . Choking [oneself]1941-oneself with opium and writing little erotic verses on vellum was not [his]111-flambeau notion of how [a gentleman]746-a gentleman should go to the devil . As [the two]1943-the two paused on the door - step , before taking a turn in [the garden]629-the garden , the front garden gate was thrown open with violence , and [a young man with a billycock hat on the back of [his]1945-a young man with a billycock hat on the back of his head head]1945-a young man with a billycock hat on the back of his head tumbled up the steps in [his]1945-a young man with a billycock hat on the back of his head eagerness . " [You]696-the doctor do n't understand , "[121-father brown] said [Father Brown]121-father brown , shaking [his]121-father brown head . " The shape of [this house]1895-this house is quaint - it is even laughable . But there is nothing wrong about [it]1895-this house . "[121-father brown]

As [they]1970-they spoke [they]1970-they came round the curve of glass that ended [the conservatory]701-the conservatory , an uninterrupted curve , for there was neither door nor window by which to enter at that end . The glass , however , was clear , and the sun still bright , though beginning to set ; and [they]1970-they could see not only the flamboyant blossoms inside , but the frail figure of [the poet in a brown velvet coat lying languidly on the sofa , having , apparently , fallen half asleep over a book]1972-the poet in a brown velvet coat lying languidly on the sofa , having , apparently , fallen half asleep over a book . [He]1972-the poet in a brown velvet coat lying languidly on the sofa , having , apparently , fallen half asleep over a book was [a pale , slight man]1973-a pale , slight man , with loose , chestnut hair and a fringe of beard that was the paradox of [his]1972-the poet in a brown velvet coat lying languidly on the sofa , having , apparently , fallen half asleep over a book face , for the beard made [him]1972-the poet in a brown velvet coat lying languidly on the sofa , having , apparently , fallen half asleep over a book look less manly . These traits were well known to [all three of [them]1974-all three of them]1974-all three of them ; but even had it not been so , it may be doubted whether [they]1974-all three of them would have looked at [Quinton]210-quinton just then . [Their]1974-all three of them eyes were riveted on another object .

Exactly in [their]1970-they path , immediately outside the round end of [the glass building]1975-the glass building , was standing [a tall man]1976-a tall man , whose drapery fell to [his]1976-a tall man [feet in faultless white , and whose bare , brown skull , face , and neck gleamed in the setting sun like splendid bronze]1977-feet in faultless white , and whose bare , brown skull , face , and neck gleamed in the setting sun like splendid bronze . [He]1976-a tall man was looking through the glass at [the sleeper]1978-the sleeper , and [he]1976-a tall man was more motionless than a mountain .

" Good evening , [sir]3294-sir . Do [you]3294-sir want anything ? "[111-flambeau]

Quite slowly , like [a great ship]1981-a great ship turning into [a harbour]1982-a harbour , the great yellow face turned , and looked at last over [its]1983-its white shoulder . The sunlight was still a reality , but it was the red light of evening , and the bulk of [the garden]629-the garden trees and bushes grew blacker and blacker against it . " When [that Indian]4259-that indian spoke to [us]2015-the two friends , "[121-father brown] went on [Brown]121-father brown in a conversational undertone , " [I]121-father brown had a sort of vision , a vision of [him]4259-that indian and all [his]4259-that indian universe . " Yes , "[211-dr. harris] answered [Harris]211-dr. harris . " [They]3359-the police ought to be [here]3296-here in ten minutes . "[211-dr. harris]

" Will [you]696-the doctor do [me]374-the priest a favour ? "[374-the priest] said [the priest]374-the priest quietly . " The truth is , [I]121-father brown make a collection of these curious stories , which often contain , as in the case of [[our]4282-our Hindoo friend]4283-our hindoo friend , elements which can hardly be put into a police report . " [I]121-father brown sometimes think that [you]696-the doctor know some details of this matter which [you]696-the doctor have not thought fit to mention . [The doctor]696-the doctor , who had been listening thoughtfully with [his]696-the doctor head a little on one side , looked [the priest]374-the priest in the face for an instant , and said : " All right , "[696-the doctor] and went into [the study]728-the study , closing the door behind [him]696-the doctor .

" [Flambeau]111-flambeau , "[121-father brown] said [Father Brown]121-father brown , " there is a long seat there under [the veranda]4284-the veranda , where [we]2082-we can smoke out of the rain . [They]2082-we established [themselves]2082-we comfortably in the veranda seat ; [Father Brown]121-father brown , against [his]121-father brown common habit , accepted a good cigar and smoked it steadily in silence , while the rain shrieked and rattled on the roof of [the veranda]4284-the veranda .

" [[My]121-father brown friend]3397-my friend , "[121-father brown] [he]121-father brown said at length , " this is a very queer case . A very queer case . "[121-father brown]

" [I]111-flambeau should think it was , "[111-flambeau] said [Flambeau]111-flambeau , with something like a shudder .

" [You]111-flambeau call it queer , and [I]482-the other call it queer , "[482-the other] said [the other]482-the other , " and yet [we]2082-we mean quite opposite things . The modern mind always mixes up two different ideas : mystery in the sense of what is marvellous , and mystery in the sense of what is complicated . That is half its difficulty about miracles . A miracle is startling ; but it is simple . It is simple because it is a miracle . It is power coming directly from [God]120-god or [the devil]840-the devil instead of indirectly through nature or human wills . Now , [you]4289-you mean that this business is marvellous because it is miraculous , because it is witchcraft worked by [a wicked Indian]4290-a wicked indian . Understand , [I]482-the other do not say that it was not spiritual or diabolic . Heaven and hell only know by what surrounding influences strange sins come into the lives of [men]3431-men . But for the present [my]482-the other point is this : If it was pure magic , as [you]4289-you think , then it is marvellous ; but it is not mysterious - that is , it is not complicated . The quality of a miracle is mysterious , but its manner is simple . Now , the manner of this business has been the reverse of simple . "[482-the other]

The storm that had slackened for a little seemed to be swelling again , and there came heavy movements as of faint thunder . [Father Brown]121-father brown let fall the ash of [his]121-father brown cigar and went on :

eyes , which are very penetrating ones . Can it be possible that

there is something in all that stuff of yours after all ?

[I]0-i am [a man who has ever since boyhood believed in Nature and

in all natural functions and instincts , whether [men]3431-men called them

moral or immoral]2100-a man who has ever since boyhood believed in nature and in all natural functions and instincts , whether men called them moral or immoral . Long before [I]0-i became [a doctor]2102-a doctor , when [I]0-i was [a

schoolboy keeping mice and spiders]2103-a schoolboy keeping mice and spiders , [I]0-i believed that to be a good

animal is the best thing in [the world]322-the world . But just now [I]0-i am shaken ;

[I]0-i have believed in [Nature]138-nature ; but it seems as if Nature could betray

[a man]416-a man . Can there be anything in [your]374-the priest bosh ? [I]0-i am really getting

morbid .

[I]0-i loved [[Quinton]208-quinton 's wife]2021-quinton 's wife . What was there wrong in that ? [Nature]138-nature

told [me]0-i to , and it 's love that makes [the world]322-the world go round . [I]0-i also

thought quite sincerely that [she]2021-quinton 's wife would be happier with a clean

animal like [me]0-i than with [that tormenting little lunatic]2108-that tormenting little lunatic . What was

there wrong in that ? [I]0-i was only facing facts , like [a man of

science]2109-a man of science . [She]2021-quinton 's wife would have been happier .

According to [my]0-i own creed [I]0-i was quite free to kill [Quinton]208-quinton ,

which was the best thing for [everybody]375-everybody , even [himself]208-quinton . But as a

healthy animal [I]0-i had no notion of killing [myself]0-i . [I]0-i resolved ,

therefore , that [I]0-i would never do it until [I]0-i saw a chance that

would leave [me]0-i scot free . [I]0-i saw that chance this morning .

[I]0-i have been three times , all told , into [[Quinton]208-quinton 's study]1950-quinton 's study today .

The Sins of [Prince Saradine]225-prince saradine

When [Flambeau]111-flambeau took [his]111-flambeau month 's holiday from [[his]111-flambeau office]1097-his office in [Westminster]24-westminster [he]111-flambeau took [it]2140-it in [a small sailing - boat]2141-a small sailing - boat , so small that [it]2141-a small sailing - boat passed much of its time as [a rowing - boat]2142-a rowing - boat . [He]111-flambeau took [it]2141-a small sailing - boat , moreover , in [little rivers in [the Eastern counties]3896-the eastern counties]2143-little rivers in the eastern counties , [rivers so small that [the boat]313-the boat looked like [a magic boat]2147-a magic boat , sailing on [land through meadows]2148-land through meadows and cornfields]2145-rivers so small that the boat looked like a magic boat , sailing on land through meadows and cornfields . [The vessel]2149-the vessel was just comfortable for [two people]2150-two people ; there was room only for necessities , and [Flambeau]111-flambeau had stocked [it]2149-the vessel with such things as [his]111-flambeau special philosophy considered necessary . [They]2151-they reduced [themselves]2151-they , apparently , to four essentials : tins of salmon , if [he]111-flambeau should want to eat ; loaded revolvers , if [he]111-flambeau should want to fight ; a bottle of brandy , presumably in case [he]111-flambeau should faint ; and [a priest]3432-a priest , presumably in case [he]111-flambeau should die . With this light luggage [he]111-flambeau crawled down [the little Norfolk rivers]2153-the little norfolk rivers , intending to reach [the Broads]74-the broads at last , but meanwhile delighting in [the overhanging gardens]2154-the overhanging gardens and [meadows]2155-meadows , [the mirrored mansions]2156-the mirrored mansions or [villages]2157-villages , lingering to fish in [the pools and corners]2158-the pools and corners , and in some sense hugging [the shore]2159-the shore .

Like [a true philosopher]2160-a true philosopher , [Flambeau]111-flambeau had no aim in [his]111-flambeau holiday ; but , like [a true philosopher]2160-a true philosopher , [he]111-flambeau had an excuse . [He]111-flambeau had a sort of half purpose , which [he]111-flambeau took just so seriously that its success would crown the holiday , but just so lightly that its failure would not spoil it . Years ago , when [he]111-flambeau had been [a king of [thieves]4196-thieves]2162-a king of thieves and [the most famous figure in [Paris]35-paris]2164-the most famous figure in paris , [he]111-flambeau had often received wild communications of approval , denunciation , or even love ; but [one]412-one had , somehow , stuck in [his]111-flambeau memory . It consisted simply of a visiting - card , in an envelope with an English postmark . On the back of the card was written in French and in green ink : " If [you]4304-you ever retire and become respectable , come and see [me]412-one . [I]412-one want to meet [you]4304-you , for [I]412-one have met [all the other great men of [my]412-one time]4305-all the other great men of my time . That trick of yours of getting [one detective]4306-one detective to arrest the other was the most splendid scene in French history . "[412-one] On the front of the card was engraved in the formal fashion , " [Prince Saradine]225-prince saradine , [Reed House]75-reed house , [Reed Island]82-reed island , [Norfolk]9-norfolk . "[111-flambeau]

[He]111-flambeau had not troubled much about [the prince]2166-the prince then , beyond ascertaining that [he]111-flambeau had been [a brilliant and fashionable figure in southern [Italy]77-italy]2167-a brilliant and fashionable figure in southern italy . In [his]111-flambeau youth , it was said , [he]111-flambeau had eloped with [a married woman of high rank]2168-a married woman of high rank ; the escapade was scarcely startling in [his]111-flambeau social world , but it had clung to [men]3431-men 's minds because of an additional tragedy : the alleged suicide of [the insulted husband]2170-the insulted husband , who appeared to have flung [himself]2170-the insulted husband over a precipice in [Sicily]78-sicily . [The prince]2166-the prince then lived in [Vienna]79-vienna for a time , but [his]2166-the prince more recent years seemed to have been passed in perpetual and restless travel . But when [Flambeau]111-flambeau , like [the prince]2166-the prince [himself]111-flambeau , had left [European]80-european celebrity and settled in [England]5-england , it occurred to [him]111-flambeau that [he]111-flambeau might pay a surprise visit to this eminent exile in [the Norfolk Broads]81-the norfolk broads . Whether [he]111-flambeau should find [the place]3350-the place [he]111-flambeau had no idea ; and , indeed , [it]3350-the place was sufficiently small and forgotten . But , as things fell out , [he]111-flambeau found it much sooner than [he]111-flambeau expected .

[They]2174-they had moored [[their]2174-they boat]2175-their boat one night under [a bank veiled in high grasses and short pollarded trees]2176-a bank veiled in high grasses and short pollarded trees . Sleep , after heavy sculling , had come to [them]2174-they early , and by a corresponding accident [they]2174-they awoke before it was light . To speak more strictly , [they]2174-they awoke before it was daylight ; for a large lemon moon was only just setting in [the forest of high grass above [their]2174-they heads]2177-the forest of high grass above their heads , and the sky was of a vivid violet - blue , nocturnal but bright . [Both men]2178-both men had simultaneously a reminiscence of childhood , of the elfin and adventurous time when tall weeds close over [us]2179-us like woods . Standing up thus against the large low moon , the daisies really seemed to be giant daisies , the dandelions to be giant dandelions . Somehow it reminded [them]2174-they of the dado of a nursery wall - paper . The drop of [the river - bed]2180-the river - bed sufficed to sink them under the roots of all shrubs and flowers and make [them]2174-they gaze upwards at the grass . " By [Jove]226-jove ! "[111-flambeau] said [Flambeau]111-flambeau , " it 's like being in fairyland . "[111-flambeau]

[Father Brown]121-father brown sat bolt upright in [the boat]313-the boat and crossed [himself]121-father brown . [His]121-father brown movement was so abrupt that [[his]121-father brown friend]3351-his friend asked [him]121-father brown , with a mild stare , what was the matter .

" [The people who wrote the mediaeval ballads]4307-the people who wrote the mediaeval ballads , "[374-the priest] answered [the priest]374-the priest , " knew more about fairies than [you]121-father brown do . It is n't only nice things that happen in fairyland . "[374-the priest]

" Oh , bosh ! "[111-flambeau] said [Flambeau]111-flambeau . " Only nice things could happen under such an innocent moon . [I]111-flambeau am for pushing on now and seeing what does really come . [We]2184-they may die and rot before [we]2184-they ever see again such a moon or such a mood . "[111-flambeau]

" All right , "[121-father brown] said [Father Brown]121-father brown . " [I]121-father brown never said it was always wrong to enter [fairyland]4308-fairyland . [I]121-father brown only said it was always dangerous . "[121-father brown]

[They]2184-they pushed slowly up [the brightening river]2185-the brightening river ; the glowing violet of the sky and the pale gold of the moon grew fainter and fainter , amd faded into that vast colourless cosmos that precedes the colours of the dawn . When the first faint stripes of red and gold and grey split the horizon from end to end they were broken by the black bulk of [[a town]2186-a town or village which sat on [the river]752-the river just ahead of [them]2184-they]2187-a town or village which sat on the river just ahead of them . It was already an easy twilight , in which all things were visible , when [they]2184-they came under the hanging roofs and bridges of [this riverside hamlet]2189-this riverside hamlet . [The houses]2190-the houses , with [their]2190-the houses long , low , stooping roofs , seemed to come down to drink at [the river]752-the river , like huge grey and red cattle . The broadening and whitening dawn had already turned to working daylight before [they]2184-they saw any living creature on [the wharves and bridges of [that silent town]2193-that silent town]2192-the wharves and bridges of that silent town . Eventually [they]2184-they saw [a very placid and prosperous man in [his]2194-a very placid and prosperous man in his shirt sleeves , with a face as round as the recently sunken moon , and rays of red whisker around the low arc of it , who was leaning on a post above the sluggish tide shirt sleeves , with a face as round as the recently sunken moon , and rays of red whisker around the low arc of it , who was leaning on a post above the sluggish tide]2194-a very placid and prosperous man in his shirt sleeves , with a face as round as the recently sunken moon , and rays of red whisker around the low arc of it , who was leaning on a post above the sluggish tide . By an impulse not to be analysed , [Flambeau]111-flambeau rose to [his]111-flambeau full height in [the swaying boat]2195-the swaying boat and shouted at [the man]315-the man to ask if [he]315-the man knew [Reed Island]82-reed island or [Reed House]75-reed house . [The prosperous man]2197-the prosperous man 's smile grew slightly more expansive , and [he]2197-the prosperous man simply pointed up [the river]752-the river towards [the next bend of [it]752-the river]2199-the next bend of it . [Flambeau]111-flambeau went ahead without further speech .

[The boat]313-the boat took [many such grassy corners]2201-many such grassy corners and followed [many such reedy and silent reaches of river]2202-many such reedy and silent reaches of river ; but before the search had become monotonous [they]2184-they had swung round a specially sharp angle and come into the silence of [a sort of pool or lake]2203-a sort of pool or lake , the sight of which instinctively arrested [them]2184-they . For in the middle of [this wider piece of water]2204-this wider piece of water , fringed on every side with rushes , lay [a long , low islet]2205-a long , low islet , along which ran [a long , low house or bungalow built of bamboo or some kind of tough tropic cane]2206-a long , low house or bungalow built of bamboo or some kind of tough tropic cane . The upstanding rods of bamboo which made the walls were pale yellow , the sloping rods that made the roof were of darker red or brown , otherwise [the long house]2207-the long house was a thing of repetition and monotony . The early morning breeze rustled the reeds round [the island]2208-the island and sang in [the strange ribbed house]2209-the strange ribbed house as in a giant pan - pipe .

" By [George]227-george ! "[111-flambeau] cried [Flambeau]111-flambeau ; " here is [the place]3350-the place , after all ! Here is [Reed Island]82-reed island , if ever there was one . Here is [Reed House]75-reed house , if it is anywhere . [I]111-flambeau believe [that fat man with whiskers]4310-that fat man with whiskers was [a fairy]466-a fairy . "[111-flambeau]

" Perhaps , "[121-father brown] remarked [Father Brown]121-father brown impartially . " If [he]4310-that fat man with whiskers was , [he]4310-that fat man with whiskers was [a bad fairy]4312-a bad fairy . "[121-father brown]

But even as [he]111-flambeau spoke the impetuous [Flambeau]111-flambeau had run [[his]111-flambeau boat]2210-his boat ashore in [the rattling reeds]2211-the rattling reeds , and [they]2212-they stood in [the long , quaint islet beside [the odd and silent house]2214-the odd and silent house]2213-the long , quaint islet beside the odd and silent house .

[The house]630-the house stood with [its]630-the house back , as [it]630-the house were , to [the river]752-the river and the only landing - stage ; the main entrance was on the other side , and looked down [the long island garden]2217-the long island garden . [The visitors]2218-the visitors approached [it]630-the house , therefore , by a small path running round nearly three sides of [the house]630-the house , close under the low eaves . Through three different windows on three different sides [they]2218-the visitors looked in on [the same long , well - lit room]2220-the same long , well - lit room , panelled in light wood , with a large number of looking - glasses , and laid out as for an elegant lunch . The front door , when [they]2218-the visitors came round to [it]630-the house at last , was flanked by two turquoise - blue flower pots . It was opened by [a butler of the drearier type]2221-a butler of the drearier type - long , lean , grey and listless - who murmured that [Prince Saradine]225-prince saradine was from [home]3338-home at present , but was expected hourly ; [the house]630-the house being kept ready for [him]225-prince saradine and [[his]225-prince saradine guests]619-his guests . The exhibition of the card with the scrawl of green ink awoke a flicker of life in the parchment face of [the depressed retainer]2225-the depressed retainer , and it was with a certain shaky courtesy that [he]2221-a butler of the drearier type suggested that [the strangers]2226-the strangers should remain . " [[His]225-prince saradine Highness]4313-his highness may be [here]3296-here any minute , "[2221-a butler of the drearier type] [he]2221-a butler of the drearier type said , " and would be distressed to have just missed [any gentleman [he]4313-his highness had invited]4315-any gentleman he had invited . [We]4316-we have orders always to keep a little cold lunch for [him]225-prince saradine and [[his]225-prince saradine friends]4317-his friends , and [I]2221-a butler of the drearier type am sure [he]225-prince saradine would wish it to be offered . "[2221-a butler of the drearier type]

Moved with curiosity to this minor adventure , [Flambeau]111-flambeau assented gracefully , and followed [the old man]2227-the old man , who ushered [him]111-flambeau ceremoniously into [the long , lightly panelled room]2228-the long , lightly panelled room . There was nothing very notable about [it]2228-the long , lightly panelled room , except the rather unusual alternation of many long , low windows with many long , low oblongs of looking - glass , which gave a singular air of lightness and unsubstantialness to [the place]3350-the place . It was somehow like lunching out of doors . One or two pictures of a quiet kind hung in the corners , one a large grey photograph of [a very young man in uniform]2230-a very young man in uniform , another a red chalk sketch of [two long - haired boys]2231-two long - haired boys . Asked by [Flambeau]111-flambeau whether [the soldierly person]2232-the soldierly person was [the prince]2166-the prince , [the butler]4044-the butler answered shortly in the negative ; it was [[the prince]2166-the prince 's younger brother]2236-the prince 's younger brother , [Captain Stephen Saradine]228-captain stephen saradine , [he]4044-the butler said . And with that [the old man]2227-the old man seemed to dry up suddenly and lose all taste for conversation .

After lunch had tailed off with exquisite coffee and liqueurs , [the guests]637-the guests were introduced to [the garden]629-the garden , [the library]3481-the library , and [the housekeeper]2241-the housekeeper - [a dark , handsome lady , of no little majesty]2242-a dark , handsome lady , of no little majesty , and rather like [a plutonic Madonna]2243-a plutonic madonna . It appeared that [she]2241-the housekeeper and [the butler]4044-the butler were [the only survivors of [the prince]2166-the prince 's original foreign menage [the other servants now in [the house]630-the house]2247-the other servants now in the house being new and collected in [Norfolk]9-norfolk by [the housekeeper]2241-the housekeeper]2245-the only survivors of the prince 's original foreign menage the other servants now in the house being new and collected in norfolk by the housekeeper . [This latter lady]2250-this latter lady went by the name of [Mrs. Anthony]229-mrs. anthony , but [she]2250-this latter lady spoke with a slight Italian accent , and [Flambeau]111-flambeau did not doubt that [Anthony]229-mrs. anthony was a [Norfolk]9-norfolk version of some more Latin name . [Mr. Paul]230-mr. paul , [the butler]4044-the butler , also had a faintly foreign air , but [he]230-mr. paul was in tongue and training English , as are [many of the most polished men]2252-many of the most polished men - [servants of the cosmopolitan nobility]2253-servants of the cosmopolitan nobility .

Pretty and unique as [it]630-the house was , [the place]3350-the place had about [it]630-the house a curious luminous sadness . Hours passed in [it]630-the house like days . [The long , well - windowed rooms]2255-the long , well - windowed rooms were full of daylight , but it seemed a dead daylight . And through all other incidental noises , the sound of talk , the clink of glasses , or the passing feet of [servants]2256-servants , [they]2257-they could hear on all sides of [the house]630-the house the melancholy noise of [the river]752-the river .

" [We]2257-they have taken a wrong turning , and come to a wrong place , "[121-father brown] said [Father Brown]121-father brown , looking out of the window at the grey - green sedges and the silver flood . " Never mind ; [one]412-one can sometimes do good by being [the right person in [the wrong place]4320-the wrong place]4319-the right person in the wrong place . "[121-father brown]

[Father Brown]121-father brown , though [commonly a silent]2260-commonly a silent , was [an oddly sympathetic little man]2261-an oddly sympathetic little man , and in those few but endless hours [he]121-father brown unconsciously sank deeper into the secrets of [Reed House]75-reed house than [[his]121-father brown professional friend]2262-his professional friend . [He]121-father brown had that knack of friendly silence which is so essential to gossip ; and saying scarcely a word , [he]121-father brown probably obtained from [[his]121-father brown new acquaintances]2263-his new acquaintances all that in any case [they]2263-his new acquaintances would have told . [The butler]4044-the butler indeed was naturally uncommunicative . [He]4044-the butler betrayed a sullen and almost animal affection for [[his]4044-the butler master]786-his master ; who , [he]4044-the butler said , had been very badly treated . [The chief offender]2266-the chief offender seemed to be [[[his]4044-the butler highness]4313-his highness 's brother]2268-his highness 's brother , whose name alone would lengthen [the old man]2227-the old man 's lantern jaws and pucker [his]2227-the old man parrot nose into a sneer . [Captain Stephen]228-captain stephen saradine was [a ne'er - do - weel , apparently , and had drained [[his]228-captain stephen saradine benevolent brother]2271-his benevolent brother of hundreds and thousands]2270-a ne'er - do - weel , apparently , and had drained his benevolent brother of hundreds and thousands ; forced [him]228-captain stephen saradine to fly from fashionable life and live quietly in [this retreat]2272-this retreat . That was all [Paul]230-mr. paul , [the butler]4044-the butler , would say , and [Paul]230-mr. paul was obviously [a partisan]2274-a partisan .

[The Italian housekeeper]2275-the italian housekeeper was somewhat more communicative , being , as [Brown]121-father brown fancied , somewhat less content . [Her]2275-the italian housekeeper tone about [[her]2275-the italian housekeeper master]2276-her master was faintly acid ; though not without a certain awe . [Flambeau]111-flambeau and [[his]111-flambeau friend]3351-his friend were standing in the room of the looking - glasses examining the red sketch of [the two boys]2278-the two boys , when [the housekeeper]2241-the housekeeper swept in swiftly on some domestic errand . It was a peculiarity of this glittering , glass - panelled place that [anyone entering]2280-anyone entering was reflected in four or five mirrors at once ; and [Father Brown]121-father brown , without turning round , stopped in the middle of a sentence of family criticism . But [Flambeau]111-flambeau , who had [his]111-flambeau face close up to the picture , was already saying in a loud voice , " [The brothers Saradine]4321-the brothers saradine , [I]111-flambeau suppose . [They]4321-the brothers saradine both look innocent enough . It would be hard to say which is [the good brother]4322-the good brother and which the bad . "[111-flambeau] Then , realising [the lady]1549-the lady 's presence , [he]121-father brown turned the conversation with some triviality , and strolled out into [the garden]629-the garden . But [Father Brown]121-father brown still gazed steadily at the red crayon sketch ; and [Mrs. Anthony]229-mrs. anthony still gazed steadily at [Father Brown]121-father brown .

[She]229-mrs. anthony had large and tragic brown eyes , and [her]229-mrs. anthony olive face glowed darkly with a curious and painful wonder - as of one doubtful of [a stranger]2283-a stranger 's identity or purpose . Whether [the little priest]363-the little priest 's coat and creed touched some southern memories of confession , or whether [she]229-mrs. anthony fancied [he]121-father brown knew more than [he]121-father brown did , [she]229-mrs. anthony said to [him]121-father brown in a low voice as to [a fellow plotter]2285-a fellow plotter , " [He]121-father brown is right enough in one way , [[your]121-father brown friend]3738-your friend . "[229-mrs. anthony]

" [I]121-father brown do n't understand [you]532-the woman , "[121-father brown] said [Father Brown]121-father brown , and began to move away .

[The woman]532-the woman took a step nearer to [him]121-father brown , with thunderous brows and a sort of savage stoop , like a bull lowering [his]121-father brown horns .

" There is n't [a good one]4325-a good one , "[229-mrs. anthony] [she]229-mrs. anthony hissed . A light dawned on [the cleric]901-the cleric 's averted face , and [his]121-father brown mouth formed silently the word " blackmail . "[121-father brown] Even as [he]121-father brown did so [the woman]532-the woman turned an abrupt white face over [her]532-the woman shoulder and almost fell . The door had opened soundlessly and [the pale Paul]2289-the pale paul stood like a ghost in the doorway . " [[His]121-father brown Highness]4313-his highness , "[121-father brown] [he]121-father brown said , " has just arrived . "[121-father brown]

In the same flash the figure of [a man]416-a man had passed outside the first window , crossing the sunlit pane like a lighted stage . An instant later [he]121-father brown passed at the second window and the many mirrors repainted in successive frames [the same eagle profile and marching figure]2291-the same eagle profile and marching figure . [He]121-father brown was erect and alert , but [his]121-father brown hair was white and [his]121-father brown complexion of an odd ivory yellow . [He]121-father brown had that short , curved Roman nose which generally goes with long , lean cheeks and chin , but these were partly masked by moustache and imperial . The moustache was much darker than the beard , giving an effect slightly theatrical , and [he]121-father brown was dressed up to the same dashing part , having a white top hat , an orchid in [his]121-father brown coat , a yellow waistcoat and yellow gloves which [he]121-father brown flapped and swung as [he]121-father brown walked . " [Pleasant little place]4330-pleasant little place , this , [I]2166-the prince think , "[2166-the prince] [he]2166-the prince said with a detached air . " Not much to do , [I]2166-the prince fear ; but the fishing is really good . "[2166-the prince]

[The priest]374-the priest , who was staring at [him]2166-the prince with the grave stare of [a baby]2301-a baby , was haunted by some fancy that escaped definition . [He]374-the priest looked at the grey , carefully curled hair , yellow white visage , and slim , somewhat foppish figure . These were not unnatural , though perhaps a shade prononce , like the outfit of [a figure behind the footlights]2302-a figure behind the footlights . The nameless interest lay in something else , in the very framework of the face ; [Brown]121-father brown was tormented with a half memory of having seen it somewhere before . [The man]315-the man looked like [some old friend of [his]121-father brown]2304-some old friend of his dressed up . Then [he]121-father brown suddenly remembered the mirrors , and put [his]121-father brown fancy down to some psychological effect of that multiplication of human masks .

[Prince Saradine]225-prince saradine distributed [his]225-prince saradine social attentions between [[his]225-prince saradine guests]619-his guests with great gaiety and tact . Finding the detective of a sporting turn and eager to employ [his]225-prince saradine holiday , [he]225-prince saradine guided [Flambeau]111-flambeau and [[Flambeau]111-flambeau 's boat]2306-flambeau 's boat down to [the best fishing spot in the stream]2307-the best fishing spot in the stream , and was back in [his]225-prince saradine own canoe in twenty minutes to join [Father Brown]121-father brown in [the library]3481-the library and plunge equally politely into [the priest]374-the priest 's more philosophic pleasures . [He]225-prince saradine seemed to know a great deal both about the fishing and the books , though of these not the most edifying ; [he]225-prince saradine spoke five or six languages , though chiefly the slang of each . [He]225-prince saradine had evidently lived in [varied cities]2310-varied cities and very [motley societies]2311-motley societies , for some of [his]225-prince saradine cheerfullest stories were about [gambling hells]2312-gambling hells and [opium dens]2313-opium dens , [Australian bushrangers]2314-australian bushrangers or [Italian brigands]2315-italian brigands . [Father Brown]121-father brown knew that [the once - celebrated [Saradine]225-prince saradine]2316-the once - celebrated saradine had spent [his]225-prince saradine last few years in almost ceaseless travel , but [he]225-prince saradine had not guessed that the travels were so disreputable or so amusing .

Indeed , with all [his]225-prince saradine dignity of [a man of [the world]322-the world]2317-a man of the world , [Prince Saradine]225-prince saradine radiated to [such sensitive observers]2319-such sensitive observers as [the priest]374-the priest , a certain atmosphere of the restless and even the unreliable . [His]225-prince saradine face was fastidious , but [his]225-prince saradine eye was wild ; [he]225-prince saradine had little nervous tricks , like [a man shaken by drink or drugs]2321-a man shaken by drink or drugs , and [he]225-prince saradine neither had , nor professed to have , [his]225-prince saradine hand on the helm of household affairs . All these were left to [the two old servants]2322-the two old servants , especially to [the butler , who was plainly the central pillar of [the house]630-the house]2323-the butler , who was plainly the central pillar of the house . [Mr. Paul]230-mr. paul , indeed , was not so much [a butler]2325-a butler as [a sort of steward]2326-a sort of steward or , even , [chamberlain]2327-chamberlain ; [he]230-mr. paul dined privately , but with almost as much pomp as [[his]230-mr. paul master]786-his master ; [he]230-mr. paul was feared by [all the servants]2329-all the servants ; and [he]230-mr. paul consulted with [the prince]2166-the prince decorously , but somewhat unbendingly - rather as if [he]230-mr. paul were [[the prince]2166-the prince 's solicitor]2332-the prince 's solicitor . [The sombre housekeeper]2333-the sombre housekeeper was a mere shadow in comparison ; indeed , [she]2333-the sombre housekeeper seemed to efface [herself]2333-the sombre housekeeper and wait only on [the butler]4044-the butler , and [Brown]121-father brown heard no more of those volcanic whispers which had half told [him]121-father brown of [the younger brother who blackmailed [the elder]2336-the elder]2335-the younger brother who blackmailed the elder . Whether [the prince]2166-the prince was really being thus bled by [the absent captain]2338-the absent captain , [he]121-father brown could not be certain , but there was something insecure and secretive about [Saradine]225-prince saradine that made the tale by no means incredible .

When [they]2339-they went once more into [the long hall]2340-the long hall with the windows and the mirrors , yellow evening was dropping over [the waters]2341-the waters and [the willowy banks]2342-the willowy banks ; and [a bittern]2343-a bittern sounded in the distance like an elf upon [his]2344-his dwarfish drum . The same singular sentiment of some sad and evil fairyland crossed [the priest]374-the priest 's mind again like a little grey cloud . " [I]121-father brown wish [Flambeau]111-flambeau were back , "[121-father brown] [he]121-father brown muttered .

[The prince]2166-the prince turned from the window and stared at [him]225-prince saradine in a singular manner , [his]2166-the prince face in shadow against the sunset . " What do [you]2346-his guest mean ? "[2166-the prince] [he]2166-the prince asked .

" [I]121-father brown mean that [we]4331-we here are on the wrong side of the tapestry , "[121-father brown] answered [Father Brown]121-father brown . [The prince]2166-the prince made an inexplicable noise like an animal ; in [his]2166-the prince shadowed face the eyes were shining queerly .
