Then [Father Brown]121-father brown awoke tardily to a second truth . In the mirrors before [him]121-father brown [he]121-father brown could see the silent door standing open , and the silent [Mr. Paul]230-mr. paul standing in [it]2351-it , with [his]230-mr. paul usual pallid impassiveness .

" [I]121-father brown thought it better to announce at once , "[121-father brown] [he]121-father brown said , with the same stiff respectfulness as of [an old family lawyer]2352-an old family lawyer , " [a boat rowed by]4336-a boat rowed by [six men]4337-six men has come to the landing - stage , and there 's [a gentleman sitting in the stern]4338-a gentleman sitting in the stern . "[121-father brown]

" [A boat]4339-a boat ! "[2166-the prince] repeated [the prince]2166-the prince ; " [a gentleman]746-a gentleman ? "[2166-the prince] and [he]2166-the prince rose to [his]2166-the prince feet .

There was a startled silence punctuated only by the odd noise of the bird in the sedge ; and then , before [anyone]798-anyone could speak again , a new face and figure passed in profile round the three sunlit windows , as [the prince]2166-the prince had passed an hour or two before . But except for the accident that [both outlines]2356-both outlines were aquiline , [they]2356-both outlines had little in common . Instead of the new white topper of [Saradine]225-prince saradine , was [a black one of antiquated or foreign shape]2357-a black one of antiquated or foreign shape ; under it was a young and very solemn face , clean shaven , blue about its resolute chin , and carrying a faint suggestion of [the young Napoleon]2358-the young napoleon . The association was assisted by something old and odd about the whole get - up , as of [a man who had never troubled to change the fashions of [[his]2359-a man who had never troubled to change the fashions of his fathers fathers]2360-his fathers]2359-a man who had never troubled to change the fashions of his fathers . [He]2359-a man who had never troubled to change the fashions of his fathers had a shabby blue frock coat , a red , soldierly looking waistcoat , and a kind of coarse white trousers common among [the early Victorians]2361-the early victorians , but strangely incongruous today . From all this old clothes - shop [his]2359-a man who had never troubled to change the fashions of his fathers olive face stood out strangely young and monstrously sincere .

" [The deuce]4265-the deuce ! "[225-prince saradine] said [Prince Saradine]225-prince saradine , and clapping on [his]225-prince saradine white hat [he]225-prince saradine went to the front door [himself]225-prince saradine , flinging it open on [the sunset garden]2362-the sunset garden .

By that time [the new - comer]1533-the new - comer and [[his]1533-the new - comer followers]577-his followers were drawn up on [the lawn]727-the lawn like [a small stage army]2366-a small stage army . [The six boatmen]2367-the six boatmen had pulled [the boat]313-the boat well up on [shore]2369-shore , and were guarding [it]313-the boat almost menacingly , holding [their]2367-the six boatmen oars erect like spears . " But [Prince Saradine]225-prince saradine bore another burden besides [[his]225-prince saradine blood - sucking brother]4402-his blood - sucking brother . [He]225-prince saradine knew that [the son of [Antonelli]232-antonelli]4403-the son of antonelli , [a mere child at the time of the murder]4404-a mere child at the time of the murder , had been trained in savage Sicilian loyalty , and lived only to avenge [[his]4403-the son of antonelli father]2445-his father , not with the gibbet for [he]225-prince saradine lacked [Stephen]236-stephen 's legal proof , but with the old weapons of vendetta . [The boy]4209-the boy had practised arms with a deadly perfection , and about the time that [he]4209-the boy was old enough to use them [Prince Saradine]225-prince saradine began , as the society papers said , to travel . The fact is that [he]225-prince saradine began to flee for [his]225-prince saradine life , passing from place to place like [a hunted criminal]4407-a hunted criminal ; but with [one relentless man upon [his]225-prince saradine trail]4408-one relentless man upon his trail . That was [Prince Paul]225-prince saradine 's position , and by no means a pretty one . The more money [he]225-prince saradine spent on eluding [Antonelli]232-antonelli the less [he]225-prince saradine had to silence [Stephen]236-stephen . The more [he]225-prince saradine gave to silence [Stephen]236-stephen the less chance there was of finally escaping [Antonelli]232-antonelli . Then it was that [he]225-prince saradine showed [himself]225-prince saradine [a great man]4409-a great man - [a genius like [Napoleon]238-napoleon]4410-a genius like napoleon .[121-father brown]

" Instead of resisting [[his]225-prince saradine two antagonists]4411-his two antagonists , [he]225-prince saradine surrendered suddenly to [both of [them]4412-both of them]4412-both of them . [He]225-prince saradine gave way like [a Japanese wrestler]4413-a japanese wrestler , and [[his]225-prince saradine foes]4414-his foes fell prostrate before [him]225-prince saradine . [He]225-prince saradine gave up the race round [the world]322-the world , and [he]225-prince saradine gave up [his]225-prince saradine address to [young Antonelli]232-antonelli ; then [he]225-prince saradine gave up everything to [[his]225-prince saradine brother]4396-his brother . [He]225-prince saradine sent [Stephen]236-stephen money enough for smart clothes and easy travel , with a letter saying roughly : ` This is all [I]3351-his friend have left . [You]236-stephen have cleaned [me]3351-his friend out . [I]3351-his friend still have [a little house in [Norfolk]9-norfolk , with [servants]2256-servants and [a cellar]4419-a cellar]4417-a little house in norfolk , with servants and a cellar , and if [you]236-stephen want more from [me]3351-his friend [you]236-stephen must take that . ' [He]225-prince saradine knew that [the Sicilian]2430-the sicilian had never seen [the Saradine brothers]4424-the saradine brothers save , perhaps , in pictures ; [he]225-prince saradine knew [they]4424-the saradine brothers were somewhat alike , both having grey , pointed beards . Then [he]225-prince saradine shaved [his]225-prince saradine own face and waited . The trap worked . [The unhappy captain]4425-the unhappy captain , in [his]4425-the unhappy captain new clothes , entered [the house]630-the house in triumph as [a prince]4427-a prince , and walked upon [the Sicilian]235-the sicilian 's sword .[3351-his friend]

" There was one hitch , and it is to the honour of human nature . [Evil spirits like [Saradine]225-prince saradine]4428-evil spirits like saradine often blunder by never expecting the virtues of [mankind]4429-mankind . [He]225-prince saradine took it for granted that [the Italian]239-the italian 's blow , when it came , would be dark , violent and nameless , like the blow [it]4430-it avenged ; that [the victim]4431-the victim would be knifed at night , or shot from behind a hedge , and so die without speech . It was a bad minute for [Prince Paul]225-prince saradine when [Antonelli]232-antonelli 's chivalry proposed a formal duel , with all its possible explanations . It was then that [I]121-father brown found [him]225-prince saradine putting off in [[his]225-prince saradine boat]2210-his boat with wild eyes . [He]225-prince saradine was fleeing , bareheaded , in [an open boat]4433-an open boat before [Antonelli]232-antonelli should learn who [he]225-prince saradine was .[121-father brown]

" But , however agitated , [he]225-prince saradine was not hopeless . [He]225-prince saradine knew [the adventurer]4434-the adventurer and [he]225-prince saradine knew [the fanatic]877-the fanatic . [The little village of Bohun Beacon]2508-the little village of bohun beacon]2507-the hammer of god the little village of bohun beacon was perched on a hill so steep that the tall spire of [[its]2508-the little village of bohun beacon church]2509-its church seemed only like the peak of [a small mountain]2510-a small mountain . At the foot of [the church]3377-the church stood [a smithy , generally red with fires and always littered with hammers and scraps of iron]2512-a smithy , generally red with fires and always littered with hammers and scraps of iron ; opposite to this , over a rude cross of [cobbled paths]2513-cobbled paths , was " The Blue Boar , "[241-wilfred] [the only inn of [the place]3350-the place]2514-the only inn of the place . [The Rev.]241-wilfred and [Hon . Wilfred Bohun]242-wilfred was very devout , and was making [his]242-wilfred way to some austere exercises of prayer or contemplation at dawn . [Colonel the Hon . Norman Bohun]243-colonel bohun , [[his]243-colonel bohun elder brother]2521-his elder brother , was by no means devout , and was sitting in evening dress on the bench outside " The Blue Boar , "[243-colonel bohun] drinking what [the philosophic observer]2522-the philosophic observer was free to regard either as [his]243-colonel bohun last glass on Tuesday or [his]243-colonel bohun first on Wednesday . [The colonel]1219-the colonel was not particular .

[The Bohuns]244-the bohuns were one of the very few [aristocratic families really dating from the Middle Ages]2524-aristocratic families really dating from the middle ages , and [[their]244-the bohuns pennon]2525-their pennon had actually seen [Palestine]245-palestine . But it is a great mistake to suppose that [such houses]2526-such houses stand high in chivalric tradition . Few except the poor preserve traditions . [Aristocrats]2527-aristocrats live not in traditions but in fashions . [The Bohuns]244-the bohuns had been [Mohocks]246-mohocks under [Queen Anne]247-queen anne and [Mashers]248-mashers under [Queen Victoria]249-queen victoria . But like more than one of [the really ancient houses]2528-the really ancient houses , [they]244-the bohuns had rotted in the last two centuries into [mere drunkards]2529-mere drunkards and [dandy degenerates]2530-dandy degenerates , till there had even come a whisper of insanity . Certainly there was something hardly human about [the colonel]1219-the colonel 's wolfish pursuit of pleasure , and [his]1219-the colonel chronic resolution not to go [home]3338-home till morning had a touch of the hideous clarity of insomnia . [He]1219-the colonel was [a tall , fine animal , elderly , but with hair still startlingly yellow]2533-a tall , fine animal , elderly , but with hair still startlingly yellow . [He]1219-the colonel would have looked merely blonde and leonine , but [his]1219-the colonel blue eyes were sunk so deep in [his]1219-the colonel face that they looked black . They were a little too close together . [He]1219-the colonel had very long yellow moustaches ; on each side of them a fold or furrow from nostril to jaw , so that a sneer seemed cut into [his]1219-the colonel face . Over [his]1219-the colonel evening clothes [he]1219-the colonel wore a curious pale yellow coat that looked more like a very light dressing gown than an overcoat , and on the back of [his]1219-the colonel head was stuck an extraordinary broad - brimmed hat of a bright green colour , evidently some oriental curiosity caught up at random . [He]1219-the colonel was proud of appearing in such incongruous attires - proud of the fact that [he]1219-the colonel always made [them]244-the bohuns look congruous .

[[His]1219-the colonel brother]4396-his brother [the curate]2535-the curate had also the yellow hair and the elegance , but [he]4396-his brother was buttoned up to the chin in black , and [his]4396-his brother face was clean - shaven , cultivated , and a little nervous . [He]1219-the colonel seemed to live for nothing but [his]1219-the colonel religion ; but there were some who said notably [the blacksmith]2536-the blacksmith , who was [a Presbyterian that it was a love of Gothic architecture]2537-a presbyterian that it was a love of gothic architecture rather than of [God]120-god , and that [his]2536-the blacksmith haunting of [the church]3377-the church like a ghost was only another and purer turn of the almost morbid thirst for beauty which sent [[his]2536-the blacksmith brother]4396-his brother raging after [women]2540-women and wine . This charge was doubtful , while [the man]315-the man 's practical piety was indubitable . Indeed , the charge was mostly an ignorant misunderstanding of the love of solitude and secret prayer , and was founded on [his]1219-the colonel being often found kneeling , not before the altar , but in peculiar places , in [the crypts]2542-the crypts or [gallery]2543-gallery , or even in [the belfry]2544-the belfry . [He]1219-the colonel was at the moment about to enter [the church]3377-the church through [the yard of [the smithy]2547-the smithy]2546-the yard of the smithy , but stopped and frowned a little as [he]1219-the colonel saw [[his]1219-the colonel brother]4396-his brother 's cavernous eyes staring in the same direction . [He]2578-the village idiot had never been known to pray before . What sort of prayers was [he]2578-the village idiot saying now ? Extraordinary prayers surely .

[Wilfred Bohun]242-wilfred stood rooted to the spot long enough to see [the idiot]4213-the idiot go out into the sunshine , and even to see [[his]242-wilfred dissolute brother]2585-his dissolute brother hail [him]242-wilfred with a sort of avuncular jocularity . This ugly sunlit picture of the stupidity and cruelty of [the earth]331-the earth sent [the ascetic]2589-the ascetic finally to [his]2589-the ascetic prayers for purification and new thoughts . [He]242-wilfred went up to a pew in [the gallery]2590-the gallery , which brought [him]242-wilfred under a coloured window which [he]242-wilfred loved and always quieted [his]242-wilfred spirit ; a blue window with [an angel carrying lilies]2591-an angel carrying lilies . [He]242-wilfred began to think less of [[his]242-wilfred evil brother]2592-his evil brother , pacing like a lean lion in [his]2578-the village idiot horrible hunger . [He]242-wilfred sank deeper and deeper into those cold and sweet colours of silver blossoms and sapphire sky .

In [this place]1026-this place half an hour afterwards [he]242-wilfred was found by [Gibbs]252-gibbs , [the village cobbler , who had been sent for [him]242-wilfred in some haste]2594-the village cobbler , who had been sent for him in some haste . It was a morning of theological enigmas .

" What is it ? "[242-wilfred] asked [Wilfred Bohun]242-wilfred rather stiffly , but putting out a trembling hand for [his]242-wilfred hat .

[The atheist]2599-the atheist spoke in a tone that , coming from [him]242-wilfred , was quite startlingly respectful , and even , as it were , huskily sympathetic .

" [You]242-wilfred must excuse [me]2599-the atheist , [sir]3294-sir , "[2599-the atheist] [he]2599-the atheist said in a hoarse whisper , " but [we]4465-we did n't think it right not to let [you]3294-sir know at once . [The curate]2535-the curate followed [the cobbler]2595-the cobbler down a short winding stair which brought [them]2603-them out at an entrance rather higher than [the street]390-the street . [Bohun]242-wilfred saw the tragedy in one glance , flat underneath [him]2595-the cobbler like a plan . [The latter]565-the latter was speaking to [her]2614-the blacksmith 's wife , indeed , very rapidly , in an undertone , as [she]2614-the blacksmith 's wife , [a magnificent woman with red - gold hair]2616-a magnificent woman with red - gold hair , was sobbing blindly on a bench . Between [these two groups]2617-these two groups , and just clear of the main heap of hammers , lay [a man in evening dress]2618-a man in evening dress , spread - eagled and flat on [his]2618-a man in evening dress face . From the height above [Wilfred]242-wilfred could have sworn to every item of [his]2618-a man in evening dress costume and appearance , down to the Bohun rings upon [his]2618-a man in evening dress fingers ; but the skull was only a hideous splash , like a star of blackness and blood .

[Wilfred Bohun]242-wilfred gave but one glance , and ran down the steps into [the yard]2619-the yard . [The doctor]696-the doctor , who was [the family physician]2621-the family physician , saluted [him]242-wilfred , but [he]242-wilfred scarcely took any notice . [He]242-wilfred could only stammer out : " [[My]242-wilfred brother]4470-my brother is dead . What does it mean ? What is this horrible mystery ? "[242-wilfred] There was an unhappy silence ; and then [the cobbler]2595-the cobbler , [the most outspoken man present]2623-the most outspoken man present , answered : " Plenty of horror , [sir]3294-sir , "[2595-the cobbler] [he]2595-the cobbler said ; " but not much mystery . "[2595-the cobbler]

" What do [you]696-the doctor mean ? "[242-wilfred] asked [Wilfred]242-wilfred , with a white face .

" It 's plain enough , "[252-gibbs] answered [Gibbs]252-gibbs . " There is only one man for forty miles round that could have struck such a blow as that , and [he]2618-a man in evening dress 's [the man that had most reason to]4472-the man that had most reason to . "[252-gibbs]

[Wilfred Bohun]241-wilfred did not smile , for humour was never [his]241-wilfred strong point . " Well , [sir]3294-sir ? "[696-the doctor] said [the doctor]696-the doctor gloomily .

" First , "[121-father brown] said [Father Brown]121-father brown quietly , " the thing is quite in [[your]3294-sir own province]4595-your own province . It is a matter of physical science . [The blacksmith]2536-the blacksmith is mistaken , not perhaps in saying that the blow was divine , but certainly in saying that it came by a miracle . It was no miracle , [doctor]3442-doctor , except in so far as [man]546-man is [himself]546-man a miracle , with [his]546-man strange and wicked and yet half - heroic heart . " Come up here , [Mr. Bohun]253-mr. bohun , "[121-father brown] [he]121-father brown called . " The air will do [you]253-mr. bohun good . "[121-father brown]

[Bohun]253-mr. bohun followed [him]121-father brown , and came out on a kind of stone gallery or balcony outside [the building]1872-the building , from which one could see the illimitable plain in which [[their]2738-their small hill]2739-their small hill stood , wooded away to the purple horizon and dotted with [villages and farms]2740-villages and farms . Clear and square , but quite small beneath [them]2738-their , was [[the blacksmith]2536-the blacksmith 's yard]2742-the blacksmith 's yard , where [the inspector]480-the inspector still stood taking notes and the corpse still lay like a smashed fly .

" Might be the map of [the world]322-the world , might n't it ? "[121-father brown] said [Father Brown]121-father brown .

" Yes , "[253-mr. bohun] said [Bohun]253-mr. bohun very gravely , and nodded [his]253-mr. bohun head .

Immediately beneath and about [them]2738-their the lines of [the Gothic building]2744-the gothic building plunged outwards into the void with a sickening swiftness akin to suicide . There is that element of Titan energy in the architecture of the Middle Ages that , from whatever aspect it be seen , it always seems to be rushing away , like the strong back of some maddened horse . [This church]2745-this church was hewn out of ancient and silent stone , bearded with old fungoids and stained with the nests of birds . And yet , when [they]2738-their saw it from below , it sprang like a fountain at the stars ; and when [they]2738-their saw it , as now , from above , it poured like a cataract into a voiceless pit . For [these two men on the tower]2746-these two men on the tower were left alone with the most terrible aspect of Gothic ; the monstrous foreshortening and disproportion , the dizzy perspectives , the glimpses of great things small and small things great ; a topsy - turvydom of stone in the mid - air . Details of stone , enormous by [their]2738-their proximity , were relieved against a pattern of [fields]4567-fields and [farms]2748-farms , pygmy in [their]2738-their distance . A carved bird or beast at a corner seemed like some vast walking or flying dragon wasting [the pastures]2749-the pastures and villages below . The whole atmosphere was dizzy and dangerous , as if [men]3431-men were upheld in air amid the gyrating wings of [colossal genii]2751-colossal genii ; and the whole of [that old church]2752-that old church , as tall and rich as [a cathedral]2753-a cathedral , seemed to sit upon [the sunlit country]2754-the sunlit country like a cloudburst .

" [I]121-father brown think there is something rather dangerous about standing on [these high places]4603-these high places even to pray , "[121-father brown] said [Father Brown]121-father brown . " Heights were made to be looked at , not to be looked from . "[121-father brown]

" Do [you]588-the other priest mean that [one]412-one may fall over , "[259-wilfred] asked [Wilfred]259-wilfred .

" [I]253-mr. bohun scarcely understand [you]588-the other priest , "[253-mr. bohun] remarked [Bohun]253-mr. bohun indistinctly .

" [I]482-the other knew [a man]416-a man , "[482-the other] [he]482-the other said , " who began by worshipping with [others]4616-others before the altar , but who grew fond of high and lonely places to pray from , corners or niches in [the belfry]2544-the belfry or the spire . [Wilfred]259-wilfred 's face was turned away , but [his]259-wilfred bony hands turned blue and white as they tightened on the parapet of stone .

" [He]482-the other thought it was given to [him]482-the other to judge [the world]322-the world and strike down [the sinner]4621-the sinner . " This also tempted [him]482-the other , that [he]482-the other had in [his]482-the other hand one of the most awful engines of nature ; [I]121-father brown mean gravitation , that mad and quickening rush by which all earth 's creatures fly back to [her]4624-her heart when released . The Eye of [Apollo]254-apollo

That singular smoky sparkle , at once a confusion and a transparency , which is the strange secret of [the Thames]86-the thames , was changing more and more from its grey to its glittering extreme as the sun climbed to the zenith over [Westminster]24-westminster , and [two men]4504-two men crossed [Westminster Bridge]87-westminster bridge . [One man]2767-one man was very tall and the other very short ; [they]4504-two men might even have been fantastically compared to [the arrogant clock - tower of [Parliament]88-parliament]2768-the arrogant clock - tower of parliament and the humbler humped shoulders of [the Abbey]2769-the abbey , for [the short man]2770-the short man was in clerical dress . The official description of [the tall man]2771-the tall man was [M. Hercule Flambeau]111-flambeau , [private detective]2772-private detective , and [he]2771-the tall man was going to [[his]2771-the tall man new offices]2773-his new offices in [a new pile of flats facing the Abbey entrance]2774-a new pile of flats facing the abbey entrance . The official description of [the short man]2770-the short man was [the Reverend [J. Brown]263-j. brown , attached to [St. Francis Xavier 's Church]89-st. francis xavier 's church]2776-the reverend j. brown , attached to st. francis xavier 's church , [Camberwell]90-camberwell , and [he]263-j. brown was coming from [a [Camberwell]90-camberwell deathbed]2777-a camberwell deathbed to see [the new offices of [[his]263-j. brown friend]3351-his friend]2778-the new offices of his friend .

[The building]1872-the building was [American]91-american in [its]1872-the building sky - scraping altitude , and [American]91-american also in the oiled elaboration of [its]1872-the building machinery of telephones and lifts . But [it]1872-the building was barely finished and still understaffed ; [only three tenants]2781-only three tenants had moved in ; [the office just above [Flambeau]111-flambeau]2782-the office just above flambeau was occupied , as also was [the office just below [him]111-flambeau]2783-the office just below him ; the two floors above that and [the three floors below]2784-the three floors below were entirely bare . But the first glance at [the new tower of flats]2785-the new tower of flats caught something much more arresting . Save for a few relics of scaffolding , the one glaring object was erected outside [the office]1028-the office just above [[Flambeau]111-flambeau 's]2787-flambeau 's . It was an enormous gilt effigy of the human eye , surrounded with rays of gold , and taking up as much room as two or three of [the office]1028-the office windows .

" What [on earth]4642-on earth is that ? "[121-father brown] asked [Father Brown]121-father brown , and stood still . " Oh , a new religion , "[111-flambeau] said [Flambeau]111-flambeau , laughing ; " one of those new religions that forgive [your]4643-your sins by saying [you]4643-your never had any . " Let [him]4644-himself look out , "[121-father brown] said [Father Brown]121-father brown . " The sun was the cruellest of all the gods . But what does that monstrous eye mean ? "[121-father brown]

" As [I]111-flambeau understand it , it is a theory of theirs , "[111-flambeau] answered [Flambeau]111-flambeau , " that [a man]416-a man can endure anything if [his]416-a man mind is quite steady . " Well , that 's all [I]111-flambeau can tell [you]3351-his friend about the new religion , "[111-flambeau] went on [Flambeau]111-flambeau carelessly . " It claims , of course , that it can cure all physical diseases . "[111-flambeau]

" Can it cure the one spiritual disease ? "[121-father brown] asked [Father Brown]121-father brown , with a serious curiosity .

" And what is the one spiritual disease ? "[111-flambeau] asked [Flambeau]111-flambeau , smiling .

" Oh , thinking one is quite well , "[3351-his friend] said [[his]111-flambeau friend]3351-his friend .

[Flambeau]111-flambeau was more interested in [the quiet little office below [him]111-flambeau]2790-the quiet little office below him than in [the flamboyant temple above]2791-the flamboyant temple above . [He]111-flambeau was [a lucid Southerner]2792-a lucid southerner , incapable of conceiving [himself]111-flambeau as anything but [a Catholic]1343-a catholic or [an atheist]677-an atheist ; and new religions of a bright and pallid sort were not much in [his]111-flambeau line . But humanity was always in [his]111-flambeau line , especially when it was good - looking ; moreover , [the ladies downstairs]2795-the ladies downstairs were characters in [their]2795-the ladies downstairs way . [The office]1028-the office was kept by [two sisters]2797-two sisters , both slight and dark , one of [them]2797-two sisters tall and striking . [She]2798-her had a dark , eager and aquiline profile , and was one of [those women whom [one]412-one always thinks of in profile , as of the clean - cut edge of some weapon]2799-those women whom one always thinks of in profile , as of the clean - cut edge of some weapon . [She]2798-her seemed to cleave [her]2798-her way through life . [She]2798-her had eyes of startling brilliancy , but it was the brilliancy of steel rather than of diamonds ; and [her]2798-her straight , slim figure was a shade too stiff for its grace . [[Her]2798-her younger sister]2801-her younger sister was like [her]2798-her shortened shadow , a little greyer , paler , and more insignificant . [They]2797-two sisters both wore a business - like black , with little masculine cuffs and collars . There are [thousands of such curt , strenuous ladies]2802-thousands of such curt , strenuous ladies in [the offices of [London]4-london]2803-the offices of london , but the interest of these lay rather in [their]2802-thousands of such curt , strenuous ladies real than [their]2802-thousands of such curt , strenuous ladies apparent position .

For [Pauline Stacey]266-pauline stacey , [the elder]2336-the elder , was actually [the heiress of a crest and half [a county]2806-a county]2805-the heiress of a crest and half a county , as well as great wealth ; [she]266-pauline stacey had been brought up in [castles]2807-castles and [gardens]893-gardens , before a frigid fierceness peculiar to [the modern woman]2809-the modern woman had driven [her]266-pauline stacey to what [she]266-pauline stacey considered a harsher and a higher existence . [She]266-pauline stacey had not , indeed , surrendered [her]266-pauline stacey money ; in that there would have been a romantic or monkish abandon quite alien to [her]266-pauline stacey masterful utilitarianism . [She]266-pauline stacey held [her]266-pauline stacey wealth , [she]266-pauline stacey would say , for use upon practical social objects . Part of it [she]266-pauline stacey had put into [her]266-pauline stacey business , the nucleus of [a model typewriting emporium]2810-a model typewriting emporium ; part of it was distributed in various leagues and causes for the advancement of such work among [women]2540-women . How far [Joan]267-joan , [[her]266-pauline stacey sister]2812-her sister and [partner]2813-partner , shared this slightly prosaic idealism [no one]3557-no one could be very sure . But [she]266-pauline stacey followed [[her]266-pauline stacey leader]2815-her leader with a dog - like affection which was somehow more attractive , with its touch of tragedy , than the hard , high spirits of [the elder]2336-the elder . For [Pauline Stacey]266-pauline stacey had nothing to say to tragedy ; [she]266-pauline stacey was understood to deny its existence .

[Her]266-pauline stacey rigid rapidity and cold impatience had amused [Flambeau]111-flambeau very much on the first occasion of [his]111-flambeau entering [the flats]3964-the flats . [He]111-flambeau had lingered outside [the lift]2818-the lift in [the entrance hall]623-the entrance hall waiting for [the lift - boy]2820-the lift - boy , who generally conducts [strangers to the various floors]2821-strangers to the various floors . But [this bright - eyed falcon of [a girl]2823-a girl]2822-this bright - eyed falcon of a girl had openly refused to endure such official delay . [She]266-pauline stacey said sharply that [she]266-pauline stacey knew all about [the lift]2818-the lift , and was not dependent on [boys]2825-boys - or [men]3431-men either . Though [[her]266-pauline stacey flat]2827-her flat was only three floors above , [she]266-pauline stacey managed in the few seconds of ascent to give [Flambeau]111-flambeau a great many of [her]266-pauline stacey fundamental views in an off - hand manner ; they were to the general effect that [she]266-pauline stacey was [a modern working woman]2828-a modern working woman and loved modern working machinery . [Her]266-pauline stacey bright black eyes blazed with abstract anger against [those who rebuke mechanic science and ask for the return of romance]2829-those who rebuke mechanic science and ask for the return of romance . [Everyone]3452-everyone , [she]266-pauline stacey said , ought to be able to manage machines , just as [she]266-pauline stacey could manage [the lift]2818-the lift . [She]266-pauline stacey seemed almost to resent the fact of [Flambeau]111-flambeau opening the lift - door for [her]266-pauline stacey ; and [that gentleman]3471-that gentleman went up to [[his]3471-that gentleman own apartments]2833-his own apartments smiling with somewhat mingled feelings at the memory of such spit - fire self - dependence .

[She]266-pauline stacey certainly had a temper , of a snappy , practical sort ; the gestures of [her]266-pauline stacey thin , elegant hands were abrupt or even destructive . Once [Flambeau]111-flambeau entered [[her]266-pauline stacey office]2834-her office on some typewriting business , and found [she]266-pauline stacey had just flung a pair of spectacles belonging to [[her]266-pauline stacey sister]2812-her sister into the middle of the floor and stamped on them . [She]266-pauline stacey was already in the rapids of an ethical tirade about the ' sickly medical notions " and the morbid admission of weakness implied in such an apparatus . [She]266-pauline stacey dared [[her]266-pauline stacey sister]2812-her sister to bring such artificial , unhealthy rubbish into [the place]3350-the place again . [She]266-pauline stacey asked if [she]266-pauline stacey was expected to wear wooden legs or false hair or glass eyes ; and as [she]266-pauline stacey spoke [her]266-pauline stacey eyes sparkled like the terrible crystal .[266-pauline stacey]

[Flambeau]111-flambeau , quite bewildered with this fanaticism , could not refrain from asking [Miss Pauline]268-miss pauline with direct French logic why a pair of spectacles was a more morbid sign of weakness than a lift , and why , if science might help [us]2836-us in the one effort , it might not help [us]2836-us in the other .

" That is so different , "[266-pauline stacey] said [Pauline Stacey]266-pauline stacey , loftily . " Batteries and motors and all those things are marks of the force of [man]546-man - yes , [Mr. Flambeau]111-flambeau , and the force of [woman]3990-woman , too ! [We]2836-us shall take [our]2836-us turn at these great engines that devour distance and defy time . That is high and splendid - that is really science . But these nasty props and plasters [the doctors]4656-the doctors sell - why , they are just badges of poltroonery . [Doctors]4657-doctors stick on legs and arms as if [we]2836-us were born cripples and [sick slaves]4658-sick slaves . But [I]266-pauline stacey was free - born , [Mr. Flambeau]111-flambeau ! [People]338-people only think [they]338-people need these things because [they]338-people have been trained in fear instead of being trained in power and courage , just as [the silly nurses]4660-the silly nurses tell [children]4140-children not to stare at the sun , and so [they]4140-children ca n't do it without blinking . But why among the stars should there be one star [I]266-pauline stacey may not see ? "[266-pauline stacey]

" [Your]2837-this strange stiff beauty eyes , "[111-flambeau] said [Flambeau]111-flambeau , with a foreign bow , " will dazzle the sun . "[111-flambeau] For , little as [he]111-flambeau knew or cared about the new religion of [Kalon]265-kalon , [he]111-flambeau had heard of [his]111-flambeau special notion about sun - gazing .

[He]111-flambeau soon discovered that the spiritual bond between the floors above and below [him]111-flambeau was close and increasing . [The man who called [himself]2839-the man who called himself kalon [Kalon]265-kalon]2839-the man who called himself kalon was [a magnificent creature , worthy , in a physical sense]2840-a magnificent creature , worthy , in a physical sense , to be [the pontiff of [Apollo]254-apollo]2841-the pontiff of apollo . [He]2839-the man who called himself kalon was nearly as tall even as [Flambeau]111-flambeau , and very much better looking , with a golden beard , strong blue eyes , and a mane flung back like a lion 's . In [structure]2842-structure [he]2839-the man who called himself kalon was the blonde beast of [Nietzsche]93-nietzsche , but all this animal beauty was heightened , brightened and softened by genuine intellect and spirituality . If [he]2839-the man who called himself kalon looked like [one of [the great Saxon kings]2844-the great saxon kings]2843-one of the great saxon kings , [he]2839-the man who called himself kalon looked like [one of [the kings that were also saints]2846-the kings that were also saints]2845-one of the kings that were also saints . All this vulgarity could not take away from [the man called [Kalon]265-kalon]2854-the man called kalon the vivid oppression and inspiration that came from [his]2839-the man who called himself kalon soul and body . For three times in the day [the new sun - worshipper]2860-the new sun - worshipper went out on [[his]2860-the new sun - worshipper little balcony]2861-his little balcony , in the face of all [Westminster]24-westminster , to say some litany to [[his]2860-the new sun - worshipper shining lord]2862-his shining lord : once at daybreak , once at sunset , and once at the shock of noon . And it was while the shock of noon still shook faintly from [the towers of [Parliament]88-parliament and [parish church]2864-parish church]2863-the towers of parliament and parish church that [Father Brown]121-father brown , [the friend of [Flambeau]111-flambeau]2865-the friend of flambeau , first looked up and saw [the white priest of [Apollo]254-apollo]2866-the white priest of apollo .

[He]265-kalon was already in the middle of [it]2874-it ; [his]265-kalon eyes were fixed upon the flaming disc . [Father Brown]121-father brown could not look at anything without blinking ; but [the priest of [Apollo]254-apollo]2879-the priest of apollo could look on the blaze at noon without a quiver of the eyelid .

A rush and crash like the reversed rush of a rocket was cloven with a strident and incessant yelling . [Five people]2881-five people rushed into the gate of [the mansions]1566-the mansions as [three people]2883-three people rushed out , and for an instant [they]2883-three people all deafened each other . The sense of some utterly abrupt horror seemed for a moment to fill half [the street]390-the street with bad news - bad news that was all the worse because [no one]3557-no one knew what it was . [Two figures]2886-two figures remained still after the crash of commotion : [the fair priest of [Apollo]254-apollo on [the balcony above]2888-the balcony above]2887-the fair priest of apollo on the balcony above , and [the ugly priest of [Christ]272-christ below [him]2887-the fair priest of apollo on the balcony above]2889-the ugly priest of christ below him .

[Father Brown]121-father brown found [Flambeau]111-flambeau and [some six other people standing round the enclosed space into which [the lift commonly descended]2902-the lift commonly descended]2901-some six other people standing round the enclosed space into which the lift commonly descended . But [the lift]2818-the lift had not descended . Something else had descended ; something that ought to have come by [a lift]2904-a lift .

For the last four minutes [Flambeau]111-flambeau had looked down on it ; had seen the brained and bleeding figure of [that beautiful woman who denied the existence of tragedy]2905-that beautiful woman who denied the existence of tragedy . [He]111-flambeau had never had the slightest doubt that it was [Pauline Stacey]266-pauline stacey ; and , though [he]111-flambeau had sent for [a doctor]2102-a doctor , [he]111-flambeau had not the slightest doubt that [she]266-pauline stacey was dead .

[He]111-flambeau could not remember for certain whether [he]111-flambeau had liked [her]266-pauline stacey or disliked [her]266-pauline stacey ; there was so much both to like and dislike . But [she]266-pauline stacey had been [a person to [him]111-flambeau]2907-a person to him , and the unbearable pathos of details and habit stabbed [him]111-flambeau with all the small daggers of bereavement . [He]111-flambeau remembered [her]266-pauline stacey pretty face and priggish speeches with a sudden secret vividness which is all the bitterness of death . In an instant like a bolt from the blue , like a thunderbolt from nowhere , that beautiful and defiant body had been dashed down the open well of [the lift]2818-the lift to death at the bottom . Was it suicide ? With so insolent an optimist it seemed impossible . Was it murder ? But who was there in [those hardly inhabited flats]2909-those hardly inhabited flats to murder [anybody]371-anybody ? In a rush of raucous words , which [he]111-flambeau meant to be strong and suddenly found weak , [he]111-flambeau asked where was that fellow [Kalon]265-kalon . " [We]4685-we meet at last , [Caiaphas]275-caiaphas , "[2872-the prophet] said [the prophet]2872-the prophet . " [Reader of the books of evil]4696-reader of the books of evil , one more word before [I]2948-i blow away [your]275-caiaphas baseless nightmares for ever . [You]275-caiaphas said [you]275-caiaphas were offering the speech for the defence . [I]2948-i care so little for the cloudland of this life that [I]2948-i will offer [you]275-caiaphas the speech for the prosecution . There is but one thing that can be said against [me]2948-i in this matter , and [I]2948-i will say it [myself]2948-i . [The woman that is dead]4699-the woman that is dead was [my]2948-i love and [[my]2948-i bride]4700-my bride ; not after such manner as [your]275-caiaphas tin chapels call lawful , but by a law purer and sterner than [you]275-caiaphas will ever understand . [She]4699-the woman that is dead and [I]2948-i walked [another world]4701-another world from [yours]275-caiaphas , and trod palaces of crystal while [you]275-caiaphas were plodding through [tunnels and corridors of brick]4702-tunnels and corridors of brick . Well , [I]2948-i know that [policemen]4703-policemen , theological and otherwise , always fancy that where there has been love there must soon be hatred ; so there [you]275-caiaphas have the first point made for the prosecution . But the second point is stronger ; [I]2948-i do not grudge it [you]275-caiaphas . Not only is it true that [Pauline]266-pauline stacey loved [me]2948-i , but it is also true that this very morning , before [she]266-pauline stacey died , [she]266-pauline stacey wrote at that table a will leaving [me]2948-i and [[my]2948-i new church]4704-my new church half a million . [The prophet of the sun]2950-the prophet of the sun leaned easily against the mantelpiece and resumed :

" In a few words [I]2950-the prophet of the sun have put before [you]275-caiaphas the whole case against [me]2950-the prophet of the sun - the only possible case against [me]2950-the prophet of the sun . In fewer words still [I]2950-the prophet of the sun will blow it to pieces , so that not a trace of it remains . As to whether [I]2950-the prophet of the sun have committed this crime , the truth is in one sentence : [I]2950-the prophet of the sun could not have committed this crime . [Pauline Stacey]266-pauline stacey fell from this floor to the ground at five minutes past twelve . [A hundred people]4707-a hundred people will go into the witness - box and say that [I]2950-the prophet of the sun was standing out upon the balcony of [[my]2950-the prophet of the sun own rooms]4708-my own rooms above from just before the stroke of noon to a quarter - past - the usual period of [my]2950-the prophet of the sun public prayers . [[My]2950-the prophet of the sun clerk]4709-my clerk [a respectable youth from [Clapham]71-clapham , with no sort of connection with [me]2950-the prophet of the sun]4710-a respectable youth from clapham , with no sort of connection with me will swear that [he]4709-my clerk sat in [[my]2950-the prophet of the sun outer office]4711-my outer office all the morning , and that no communication passed through . [No one]3557-no one ever had so complete an alibi ; [I]2950-the prophet of the sun could subpoena half [Westminster]24-westminster . " But last of all , that no breath of this idiotic suspicion remain in the air , [I]2872-the prophet will tell [you]4715-you all [you]4715-you want to know . [I]2872-the prophet believe [I]2872-the prophet do know how [[my]2872-the prophet unhappy friend]4716-my unhappy friend came by [her]4716-my unhappy friend death . [You]4715-you can , if [you]4715-you choose , blame [me]2872-the prophet for it , or [my]2872-the prophet faith and philosophy at least ; but [you]4715-you certainly can not lock [me]2872-the prophet up . It is but a part of that general conquest of matter which is the main element in [our]4719-our occult wisdom . [Poor Pauline]276-pauline was of an impulsive and ambitious temper . [I]2872-the prophet think , to tell the truth , [she]276-pauline thought [herself]276-pauline somewhat deeper in the mysteries than [she]276-pauline was ; and [she]276-pauline has often said to [me]2872-the prophet , as [we]4719-our went down in the lift together , that if [one]412-one 's will were strong enough , [one]412-one could float down as harmlessly as a feather . The Sign of the Broken Sword

The thousand arms of [the forest]1326-the forest were grey , and its million fingers silver . In a sky of dark green - blue - like slate the stars were bleak and brilliant like splintered ice . [All that thickly wooded and sparsely tenanted countryside]2983-all that thickly wooded and sparsely tenanted countryside was stiff with a bitter and brittle frost . The black hollows between the trunks of the trees looked like bottomless , black caverns of that Scandinavian hell , a hell of incalculable cold . Even [the square stone tower of [the church]3377-the church]2984-the square stone tower of the church looked northern to the point of heathenry , as if [it]2984-the square stone tower of the church were some barbaric tower among [the sea rocks of [Iceland]97-iceland]2986-the sea rocks of iceland . It was a queer night for [anyone]798-anyone to explore [a churchyard]2988-a churchyard . But , on the other hand , perhaps it was worth exploring .

[It]2989-it rose abruptly out of [the ashen wastes of forest]2990-the ashen wastes of forest in a sort of hump or shoulder of green turf that looked grey in the starlight . Most of [the graves]2991-the graves were on a slant , and the path leading up to [the church]3377-the church was as steep as a staircase . On [the top of [the hill]1765-the hill]2993-the top of the hill , in [the one flat and prominent place]2995-the one flat and prominent place , was [the monument for which [the place]3350-the place was famous]2996-the monument for which the place was famous . [It]2996-the monument for which the place was famous contrasted strangely with the featureless graves all round , for it was the work of [one of the greatest sculptors of modern [Europe]2-europe]2998-one of the greatest sculptors of modern europe ; and yet [his]2998-one of the greatest sculptors of modern europe fame was at once forgotten in the fame of [the man whose image [he]2998-one of the greatest sculptors of modern europe had made]2999-the man whose image he had made . It showed , by touches of the small silver pencil of starlight , the massive metal figure of [a soldier recumbent , the strong hands sealed in an everlasting worship]3000-a soldier recumbent , the strong hands sealed in an everlasting worship , the great head pillowed upon a gun . The venerable face was bearded , or rather whiskered , in the old , heavy Colonel Newcome fashion . The uniform , though suggested with the few strokes of simplicity , was that of modern war . By [his]2998-one of the greatest sculptors of modern europe right side lay a sword , of which the tip was broken off ; on the left side lay a Bible . On glowing summer afternoons [wagonettes]3001-wagonettes came full of [Americans]3002-americans and [cultured suburbans]3003-cultured suburbans to see the sepulchre ; but even then [they]3001-wagonettes felt [the vast forest land]3004-the vast forest land with [[its]3004-the vast forest land one dumpy dome of [churchyard]3006-churchyard and [church]1857-church]3005-its one dumpy dome of churchyard and church as a place oddly dumb and neglected . In this freezing darkness of mid - winter one would think [he]2998-one of the greatest sculptors of modern europe might be left alone with the stars . Nevertheless , in the stillness of those stiff woods a wooden gate creaked , and [two dim figures dressed in black]3008-two dim figures dressed in black climbed up the little path to [the tomb]3009-the tomb .

So faint was that frigid starlight that nothing could have been traced about [them]3008-two dim figures dressed in black except that while [they]3008-two dim figures dressed in black both wore black , [one man]2767-one man was enormously big , and [the other perhaps]3011-the other perhaps by contrast almost startlingly small . [They]3008-two dim figures dressed in black went up to [the great graven tomb of [the historic warrior]3013-the historic warrior]3012-the great graven tomb of the historic warrior , and stood for a few minutes staring at it . There was [no human]3014-no human , perhaps no living , thing for a wide circle ; and [a morbid fancy]3015-a morbid fancy might well have wondered if [they]3008-two dim figures dressed in black were human [themselves]3008-two dim figures dressed in black . In any case , the beginning of [their]3008-two dim figures dressed in black conversation might have seemed strange . After the first silence [the small man]1486-the small man said to [the other]482-the other :

" Where does [a wise man]4385-a wise man hide a pebble ? "[1486-the small man]

And [the tall man]2771-the tall man answered in a low voice : " On [the beach]4793-the beach . "[2771-the tall man]

[The small man]1486-the small man nodded , and after a short silence said : " Where does [a wise man]4385-a wise man hide a leaf ? "[1486-the small man]

And [the other]482-the other answered : " In [the forest]1326-the forest . "[482-the other]

There was another stillness , and then [the tall man]2771-the tall man resumed : " Do [you]3023-the big man mean that when [a wise man]4385-a wise man has to hide a real diamond [he]4385-a wise man has been known to hide it among [sham ones]4797-sham ones ? "[2771-the tall man]

" No , no , "[602-the little man] said [the little man]602-the little man with a laugh , " [we]4798-we will let bygones be bygones . "[602-the little man]

[The big man]3023-the big man fumbled in [his]3023-the big man pocket , and soon a scratch and a flare painted gold the whole flat side of [the monument]3024-the monument . " [Sir Arthur St. Clare]279-st. clare was [a soldier of the old religious type]4832-a soldier of the old religious type - the type that saved [us]4833-us during the Mutiny , "[121-father brown] continued [Brown]121-father brown . " [He]279-st. clare was always more for duty than for dash ; and with all [his]279-st. clare personal courage was decidedly [a prudent commander]4834-a prudent commander , particularly indignant at any needless waste of [soldiers]4835-soldiers . [I]121-father brown will , however , add this in justice to the memories of [two distinguished men]4876-two distinguished men . " There are three more bits of evidence , "[482-the other] said [the other]482-the other , " that [I]482-the other have dug up in holes and corners ; and [I]482-the other will give them in logical rather than chronological order . First of all , of course , [our]3052-they authority for the issue and event of the battle is in [Olivier]281-olivier 's own dispatches , which are lucid enough . [He]281-olivier was entrenched with two or three regiments on [the heights that swept down to [the Black River]102-the black river]4887-the heights that swept down to the black river , on the other side of which was lower and [more marshy ground]4888-more marshy ground . Beyond this again was [gently rising country , on which was [the first English outpost]4890-the first english outpost]4889-gently rising country , on which was the first english outpost , supported by others which lay , however , considerably in [its]4890-the first english outpost rear . [The British forces as a whole]4891-the british forces as a whole were greatly superior in numbers ; but [this particular regiment]4892-this particular regiment was just far enough from [its]4892-this particular regiment base to make [Olivier]281-olivier consider the project of crossing [the river]752-the river to cut [it]752-the river off . By sunset , however , [he]281-olivier had decided to retain [[his]281-olivier own position]4894-his own position , which was a specially strong one . At daybreak next morning [he]281-olivier was thunderstruck to see that [this stray handful of English]4895-this stray handful of english , entirely unsupported from [their]4895-this stray handful of english rear , had flung [themselves]4895-this stray handful of english across [the river]752-the river , half by [a bridge to the right]4897-a bridge to the right , and the other half by a ford higher up , and were massed upon [the marshy bank below [him]281-olivier]4898-the marshy bank below him .[482-the other]

" That [they]4895-this stray handful of english should attempt an attack with such numbers against such a position was incredible enough ; but [Olivier]281-olivier noticed something yet more extraordinary . For instead of attempting to seize more solid ground , [this mad regiment]4899-this mad regiment , having put [the river]752-the river in [its]4899-this mad regiment rear by one wild charge , did nothing more , but stuck there in the mire like flies in treacle . Needless to say , [the Brazilians]282-the brazilians blew great gaps in [them]282-the brazilians with artillery , which [they]282-the brazilians could only return with spirited but lessening rifle fire . Yet [they]282-the brazilians never broke ; and [Olivier]281-olivier 's curt account ends with a strong tribute of admiration for the mystic valour of [these imbeciles]4901-these imbeciles . ` [Our]4902-our line then advanced finally , ' writes [Olivier]281-olivier , ` and drove [them]4895-this stray handful of english into [the river]752-the river ; [we]4902-our captured [General St. Clare]279-st. clare [himself]279-st. clare and [several other officers]4904-several other officers . [The colonel]1219-the colonel and [the major]4906-the major had both fallen in the battle . [I]1175-the speaker can not resist saying that few finer sights can have been seen in history than the last stand of [this extraordinary regiment]4907-this extraordinary regiment ; [wounded officers]4908-wounded officers picking up the rifles of [dead soldiers]4909-dead soldiers , and [the general]4871-the general [himself]4871-the general facing [us]4902-our on horseback bareheaded and with a broken sword . ' On what happened to [the general]4871-the general afterwards [Olivier]281-olivier is as silent as [Captain Keith]286-captain keith . "[1175-the speaker]

" Well , "[111-flambeau] grunted [Flambeau]111-flambeau , " get on to the next bit of evidence . "[111-flambeau]

[This latter]4917-this latter was a certain [Colonel Clancy]288-colonel clancy , [a big bull of an Irishman]4918-a big bull of an irishman ; and it would seem that [he]4917-this latter died almost as much of rage as of bullets . [He]4917-this latter , at any rate , was not responsible for that ridiculous raid ; it must have been imposed on [him]4917-this latter by [the general]4871-the general . [His]4917-this latter last edifying words , according to [[my]121-father brown informant]4920-my informant , were these : ` And there goes [the damned old donkey with the end of [his]4917-this latter sword knocked off]4921-the damned old donkey with the end of his sword knocked off . ' [You]4922-you will remark that [everyone]3452-everyone seems to have noticed this detail about the broken sword blade , though [most people]4478-most people regard it somewhat more reverently than did [the late Colonel Clancy]288-colonel clancy . And now for the third fragment . "[121-father brown]

[Their]3062-their path through [the woodland]3056-the woodland began to go upward , and [the speaker]1175-the speaker paused a little for breath before [he]1175-the speaker went on . Then [he]1175-the speaker continued in the same business - like tone :

" Only a month or two ago [a certain Brazilian official]4925-a certain brazilian official died in [England]5-england , having quarrelled with [Olivier]281-olivier and left [[his]4925-a certain brazilian official country]665-his country . [He]4925-a certain brazilian official was [a well - known figure both here and on [the Continent]103-the continent]4927-a well - known figure both here and on the continent , [a Spaniard named Espado]289-a spaniard named espado ; [I]1175-the speaker knew [him]4925-a certain brazilian official [myself]1175-the speaker , a yellow - faced old dandy , with a hooked nose . [I]1175-the speaker can only suppose that it was found by [the Brazilians]282-the brazilians on one of those that fell . Anyhow , it stopped abruptly the night before the battle .[1175-the speaker]

" But the account of that last day in [the poor fellow]4020-the poor fellow 's life was certainly worth reading . [I]1175-the speaker have it on [me]1175-the speaker ; but it 's too dark to read it here , and [I]1175-the speaker will give [you]4933-you a resume . The first part of that entry is full of jokes , evidently flung about among [the men]4934-the men , about somebody called the Vulture . It does not seem as if [this person]4935-this person , whoever [he]4935-this person was , was one of [themselves]4934-the men , nor even [an Englishman]4936-an englishman ; neither is [he]4935-this person exactly spoken of as [one of [the enemy]4938-the enemy]4937-one of the enemy . [He]4935-this person has been closeted with [old Colonel [Clancy]288-colonel clancy]4943-old colonel clancy ; but is more often seen talking to [the major]4906-the major . There is also some joke about the Vulture wearing bright - coloured clothes .[1175-the speaker]

" But all these levities are scattered by what may well be called the note of a bugle . Behind [the English camp]4951-the english camp and almost parallel to [the river]752-the river ran [one of the few great roads of [that district]4954-that district]4953-one of the few great roads of that district . Westward [the road]471-the road curved round towards [the river]752-the river , which [it]471-the road crossed by [the bridge before mentioned]4957-the bridge before mentioned . To the east [the road]471-the road swept backwards into [the wilds]4959-the wilds , and some two miles along [it]471-the road was [the next English outpost]4960-the next english outpost . From this direction there came along [the road]471-the road that evening a glitter and clatter of light cavalry , in which even [the simple diarist]4962-the simple diarist could recognise with astonishment [the general]4871-the general with [his]4871-the general staff . [He]4871-the general rode the great white horse which [you]4964-you have seen so often in illustrated papers and Academy pictures ; and [you]4964-you may be sure that the salute [they]4965-they gave [him]4871-the general was not merely ceremonial . [He]4871-the general , at least , wasted no time on ceremony , but , springing from the saddle immediately , mixed with [the group of officers]4966-the group of officers , and fell into emphatic though confidential speech . What struck [[our]4967-our friend]4968-our friend [the diarist]4969-the diarist most was [his]4871-the general special disposition to discuss matters with [Major Murray]290-murray ; but , indeed , such a selection , so long as it was not marked , was in no way unnatural . [The two men]1539-the two men were made for sympathy ; [they]1539-the two men were [men who ` read [their]1539-the two men Bibles]4971-men who ` read their bibles ' ; [they]1539-the two men were both [the old Evangelical type of officer]4972-the old evangelical type of officer . [The colonel]1219-the colonel had gone back to [[his]1219-the colonel tent]4982-his tent , and [the men]4934-the men to [[their]4934-the men pickets]4984-their pickets ; [the man with the diary]4985-the man with the diary lingered for another four minutes , and saw a marvellous sight .[1175-the speaker]

" The great white horse which had marched slowly down [the road]471-the road , as it had marched in so many processions , flew back , galloping up [the road]471-the road towards [them]4977-the soldiers as if it were mad to win a race . At first [they]4977-the soldiers thought it had run away with [the man on its back]4988-the man on its back ; but [they]4977-the soldiers soon saw that [the general]4871-the general , [a fine rider]4990-a fine rider , was [himself]4871-the general urging it to full speed . " [I]1175-the speaker conceive that all the earthquake events of that catastrophe tumbled on top of each other rather like lumber in the minds of [men such as [[our]4995-our friend]4968-our friend with the diary]4994-men such as our friend with the diary . [The Three Tools of Death]296-the three tools of death

Both by calling and conviction [Father Brown]121-father brown knew better than most of [us]3108-us , that [every man]3109-every man is dignified when [he]3109-every man is dead . But even [he]121-father brown felt a pang of incongruity when [he]121-father brown was knocked up at daybreak and told that [Sir Aaron Armstrong]223-sir aaron armstrong had been murdered . There was something absurd and unseemly about secret violence in connection with so entirely entertaining and popular [a figure]3110-a figure . For [Sir Aaron Armstrong]223-sir aaron armstrong was entertaining to the point of being comic ; and popular in such a manner as to be almost legendary . It was like hearing that [Sunny Jim]297-sunny jim had hanged [himself]297-sunny jim ; or that [Mr. Pickwick]298-mr. pickwick had died in [Hanwell]107-hanwell . For though [Sir Aaron]223-sir aaron armstrong was [a philanthropist]3111-a philanthropist , and thus dealt with the darker side of [[our]3108-us society]3112-our society , [he]223-sir aaron armstrong prided [himself]223-sir aaron armstrong on dealing with it in the brightest possible style . [His]223-sir aaron armstrong political and social speeches were cataracts of anecdotes and " loud laughter "[223-sir aaron armstrong] ; [his]223-sir aaron armstrong bodily health was of a bursting sort ; [his]223-sir aaron armstrong ethics were all optimism ; and [he]223-sir aaron armstrong dealt with the Drink problem [his]223-sir aaron armstrong favourite topic with that immortal or even monotonous gaiety which is so often a mark of [the prosperous total abstainer]3113-the prosperous total abstainer .

The established story of [his]223-sir aaron armstrong conversion was familiar on the more puritanic platforms and pulpits , how [he]223-sir aaron armstrong had been , when only [a boy]2442-a boy , drawn away from Scotch theology to Scotch whisky , and how [he]223-sir aaron armstrong had risen out of both and become as [he]223-sir aaron armstrong modestly put it what [he]223-sir aaron armstrong was . Yet [his]223-sir aaron armstrong wide white beard , cherubic face , and sparkling spectacles , at the numberless dinners and congresses where they appeared , made it hard to believe , somehow , that [he]223-sir aaron armstrong had ever been anything so morbid as either [a dram - drinker]3115-a dram - drinker or [a Calvinist]3116-a calvinist . [He]223-sir aaron armstrong was , [one]412-one felt , [the most seriously merry of [all the sons of [men]3431-men]3119-all the sons of men]3118-the most seriously merry of all the sons of men .

[He]223-sir aaron armstrong had lived on [the rural skirt of [Hampstead]19-hampstead]3121-the rural skirt of hampstead in [a handsome house]3122-a handsome house , high but not broad , [a modern and prosaic tower]3123-a modern and prosaic tower . The narrowest of [its]3122-a handsome house narrow sides overhung the steep green bank of [a railway]3124-a railway , and was shaken by [passing trains]3125-passing trains . [Sir Aaron Armstrong]223-sir aaron armstrong , as [he]223-sir aaron armstrong boisterously explained , had no nerves . But if [the train]3360-the train had often given a shock to [the house]630-the house , that morning the tables were turned , and it was [the house]630-the house that gave a shock to [the train]3360-the train .

The engine slowed down and stopped just beyond that point where an angle of [the house]630-the house impinged upon [the sharp slope of turf]3131-the sharp slope of turf . The arrest of most mechanical things must be slow ; but the living cause of this had been very rapid . " [I]299-magnus always knew this would happen , "[299-magnus] [he]299-magnus said aloud with brazen blandness .
